componenttext: Our next question is from Jeff Stein from Northcoast Research.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: Just want to clarify the profitability outlook for Canada. It sounded to me that 2017 is probably the year when losses are going to start coming down, so I just want to make sure I'm correct in understanding that. It sounds like this will be a year of hig
componenttext: Just want to clarify the profitability outlook for Canada. It sounded to me that 2017 is probably the year when losses are going to start coming down, so I just want to make sure I'm correct in understanding that. It sounds like this will be a year of higher losses and then, again, 2016 will also be a year of even higher. Would that be correct?

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: Jeff, this is Mike. We expect '15 and '16 to be relatively comparable in terms of the losses. And then after we open all the stores and start to get some scale, we'll see that get better in 2017.
componenttext: Jeff, this is Mike. We expect '15 and '16 to be relatively comparable in terms of the losses. And then after we open all the stores and start to get some scale, we'll see that get better in 2017.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. So just from a very high level, in terms of when you start harvesting the benefits of your capital program, it sounds like this is probably going to be kind of a trough year where you see the greatest pressure on earnings. And next year, we'll still
componenttext: Okay. So just from a very high level, in terms of when you start harvesting the benefits of your capital program, it sounds like this is probably going to be kind of a trough year where you see the greatest pressure on earnings. And next year, we'll still continue to see pressure, but you would see positive earnings growth year-on-year.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: That's currently what we're seeing today.
componenttext: That's currently what we're seeing today.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Barbara Wyckoff from CLSA.
componenttext: Our next question is from Barbara Wyckoff from CLSA.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: Could you talk about the trends in women's sportswear and accessories or the top-performing categories? What's been disappointing? And then if you could comment, please, on your return rates. You're a few years into free shipping and free returns.
componenttext: Could you talk about the trends in women's sportswear and accessories or the top-performing categories? What's been disappointing? And then if you could comment, please, on your return rates. You're a few years into free shipping and free returns.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: This is Pete. In women's sportswear, specifically, where we have the most success, it's largely kind of around what we would call our young customer segment. And the leading brand and initiative there is the Topshop performance, which has been really very
componenttext: This is Pete. In women's sportswear, specifically, where we have the most success, it's largely kind of around what we would call our young customer segment. And the leading brand and initiative there is the Topshop performance, which has been really very, very good. And I think it was mentioned in the comments, we're expanding from 50 stores to 80 this year, and then the existing stores were comping really well there. That's been a great catalyst for women's apparel in total. And to the other category, women's apparel, [indiscernible] have been pretty good. Clothes have been pretty good, and dresses have been pretty solid. With accessories, leading the way there has been in our handbag business and then our jewelry business. Those have been probably the 2 categories that have been the best performing.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: And returns?
componenttext: And returns?

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: I'll take return rates. This is Erik. We've had free shipping fee returns on nordstrom.com for 3.5 years now and so really hasn't been any change since then. In off-price, we do charge, I think, for both of those, the important thing for returns, number o
componenttext: I'll take return rates. This is Erik. We've had free shipping fee returns on nordstrom.com for 3.5 years now and so really hasn't been any change since then. In off-price, we do charge, I think, for both of those, the important thing for returns, number one, returns is a big strategic subject for us. Being great for customers, our returns is something that's long been part of our deal and that certainly includes online. So for us, a big part of the value in our approach to returns is in having returns in the store, so online purchases being able to be returned to our store at -- well over 60% of our nordstrom.com returns end up at our full-line stores. Well over 70% of HauteLook and NordstromRack returns end up at Rack stores. Last year, Rack stores [indiscernible] as Blake mentioned have an additional million visits to our Rack stores. So there is this absolute synergy. The returns, that's probably the easiest, biggest synergy subject for us to talk about when we talk about the synergies between our stores and online. So it's -- return rates have been pretty stable at nordstrom.com, and what we're seeing more is the benefit of [indiscernible] into our stores.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Ed Yruma from KeyBank Capital Markets.
componenttext: Our next question is from Ed Yruma from KeyBank Capital Markets.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: I guess, first, you guys did a lot to improve pricing transparencies here by kind of doing this We will not be undersold and then also, I guess, by changing the sale pattern that you have. I guess, as you hindsight the year, did you get the kind of gross
componenttext: I guess, first, you guys did a lot to improve pricing transparencies here by kind of doing this We will not be undersold and then also, I guess, by changing the sale pattern that you have. I guess, as you hindsight the year, did you get the kind of gross profit and sales return you would've liked out of those 2 initiatives? And then, I guess, as a follow-up, I think you mentioned that the new DC was to support free 2-day shipping. So I guess, when does that get put into place? And is there any other negative impact to the P&L from that?

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: This is Pete. Well, I think, with regards to the pricing, that was not intended to be a near-term lever to drive results. That's much more of a long-term value proposition with customers based on desire and trust and loyalty and confidence over time, and
componenttext: This is Pete. Well, I think, with regards to the pricing, that was not intended to be a near-term lever to drive results. That's much more of a long-term value proposition with customers based on desire and trust and loyalty and confidence over time, and it's important for us to be transparent on that old pricing subject. And with the way that online business has done now, the customers are way more enabled, and they've got a lot of information. And we've got to be respectful of that, responsive to it. So that's just driven how we have adjusted some of our pricing philosophies. Most of it is still based in a bit of a reaction or anything. We're trying to run a full-price business here. We have the natural rhythm cycles of markdowns that happen, which gets addressed in our clearance strategy. As you talked about, going from those 2 [indiscernible] to the 6 clearance events. But the promotional stuff is mostly just a reaction to what happens with some of the competition. That's to level that a little bit here as the year is going on and where we are now, and that -- this thing will moderate at least for now. I'm sorry, the second part of the question...

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: I can take that. The new DC opening up. We haven't announced that we're going to free 2-day shipping. The point with having additional fulfillment center is it gets closer to a big chunk of customers, or about almost half of our customers are within the 2
componenttext: I can take that. The new DC opening up. We haven't announced that we're going to free 2-day shipping. The point with having additional fulfillment center is it gets closer to a big chunk of customers, or about almost half of our customers are within the 2-day ground delivery of Pennsylvania fulfillment center. And so a bunch of -- a big chunk of our orders for those customers will be 1 to 3 days faster for them than currently is. Now we will still ship some orders from our Cedar Rapids fulfillment center to the northeast. We won't have perfect allocation there. But mainly, we continue to focus on, and the long-term strategy here is to have a fulfillment network that gets practically, at least over 90% of our customers in the United States within a 2-day ground, and this is one step in that direction.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: And the last part of your question -- this is Mike. You asked about the cost of this, and in our comments, we noted that there's an anticipated $30 million increase in expense. We haven't broken out the DC, but that included both the DC and the loyalty pr
componenttext: And the last part of your question -- this is Mike. You asked about the cost of this, and in our comments, we noted that there's an anticipated $30 million increase in expense. We haven't broken out the DC, but that included both the DC and the loyalty program.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Kimberly Greenberger from Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: Our next question is from Kimberly Greenberger from Morgan Stanley.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: Mike, I just wanted to follow up on an earlier comment you made. You mentioned that you expect earnings growth to reaccelerate after the sort of thrust of the investment program. It sounded like that reacceleration would happen around 2017. Is that a corr
componenttext: Mike, I just wanted to follow up on an earlier comment you made. You mentioned that you expect earnings growth to reaccelerate after the sort of thrust of the investment program. It sounded like that reacceleration would happen around 2017. Is that a correct read on it? Or do you think it's more of the 2018 time frame? And then just a clarification on your Trunk Club comments. I think you mentioned that you were all quite impressed with how quickly the Trunk Club business model was able to get to breakeven. I think you mentioned that it delivered a $25 million loss in 2014 for Nordstrom and $30 million in 2015 is expected. Is that differential just a step-up from purchase accounting? Or is there something about acquiring Trunk Club that actually caused them to go from breakeven to a loss situation?

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure. Kimberly, thanks for your questions. On the first one, I think what we were saying is post-2015, we would start to see earnings growth improve. I don't think we used the word accelerate, but we thought it would improve after the peak year 2015 inves
componenttext: Sure. Kimberly, thanks for your questions. On the first one, I think what we were saying is post-2015, we would start to see earnings growth improve. I don't think we used the word accelerate, but we thought it would improve after the peak year 2015 investment. The second part on Trunk Club is we did indicate operating profitability at breakeven. And you're right, the losses are related to the amortization of the purchase accounting, and so that's what contributes to that total $25 million that you mentioned.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Paul Trussell from Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: Our next question is from Paul Trussell from Deutsche Bank.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: $20 billion in sales by 2020 sounds pretty conservative to me. But using your forecast, how should we think about the margin profile of that business? I think you kind of finished this year around 15% EBITDAR, Mike. I mean, how should we think about the n
componenttext: $20 billion in sales by 2020 sounds pretty conservative to me. But using your forecast, how should we think about the margin profile of that business? I think you kind of finished this year around 15% EBITDAR, Mike. I mean, how should we think about the next few years, especially on the SG&A front?

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. Well, Paul, it might sound conservative in the numbers, but it's a heck of a lot of effort to get there. So we think we have a pretty good plan, and $20 billion is a good target for us. But anyway, in terms of how we think about the profitability, I'
componenttext: Yes. Well, Paul, it might sound conservative in the numbers, but it's a heck of a lot of effort to get there. So we think we have a pretty good plan, and $20 billion is a good target for us. But anyway, in terms of how we think about the profitability, I'd go back to what's been our long-standing guidance, and that's been the high single-digit sales growth and mid-teens ROIC. It's very difficult to predict precise margins over shorter periods of time. But our goal is to achieve -- is to target those 2 numbers and achieving them over that longer period should generate some pretty significant value.

At this point, have you guys  lit the switch, the proverbial switch, whatever that is, with fulfilling Trunk Club orders through Cedar Rapids at this point? Or where are you in that progression? And is that contemplated in the 2015 dilutive impact?

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: Neely, it's Erik. No, to answer your question. We're not fulfilling Trunk Club orders out of Cedar Rapids at this point. We have a -- they're doing that out of Chicago. What we're helping them with is -- really, it's part of our supply chain network. Whil
componenttext: Neely, it's Erik. No, to answer your question. We're not fulfilling Trunk Club orders out of Cedar Rapids at this point. We have a -- they're doing that out of Chicago. What we're helping them with is -- really, it's part of our supply chain network. While it's not in the physical location in Cedar Rapids, our team is supporting that. Here's a casual example where we got Trunk Club on our shipping contract with UPS. We've got significant savings with that. And our long-term supply chain strategy is to have everything integrated. It includes our fulfillment centers, our DC, our stores. And long term, we sort of [indiscernible] part of that. In the short term, they continue to fulfill that in Chicago.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: This is Heather Balsky on for Lorraine. Could you talk a little bit about your inventory plans going forward, especially for the Rack? How are you thinking about packing the whole investment? And then also just could you provide some color on how you're g
componenttext: This is Heather Balsky on for Lorraine. Could you talk a little bit about your inventory plans going forward, especially for the Rack? How are you thinking about packing the whole investment? And then also just could you provide some color on how you're getting to the 300 short target for the Rack? What is that based on?

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: Heather, this is Blake. Our pack-and-hold has been fairly consistent now over the last, let's say, 1.5 years or 2 years. It's about 11% of the total company's inventory, and so we continue through the vendor partnerships and relationships have a terrific
componenttext: Heather, this is Blake. Our pack-and-hold has been fairly consistent now over the last, let's say, 1.5 years or 2 years. It's about 11% of the total company's inventory, and so we continue through the vendor partnerships and relationships have a terrific access to product that's closed out in the season that we're able to clearly pack and hold in the warehouse and use the following 6 months later. It helps us turn the corner in each of the existing stores. It particularly is a key component for the new store growth. We mentioned that we opened 27 stores last year and 27 this year. Pack-and-hold enables us to execute that. So that's an approach with our vendor partnerships and vendor. Our inventory maximization that's -- we're really pleased with them working well. In terms of the 300 stores, it's a pretty fluid model opening the Rack's in terms of the lead time, particularly compared to full-line stores. And we're just learning with each one, and we continue to get great reception from the customer. I think it's really reflected in, and we've said this before, in the productivity of the stores. They both maintain and enhance slightly with the addition of these new stores. So we're encouraged by those opportunities. Sometimes there are some vagaries in the retail or the real estate market year-to-year, but we feel very confident looking ahead between now and 2020, given the criteria we use for new stores, the customer demand, the opportunities that are out there. And we feel very confident to publicly state that we should have cleaner stores by 2020.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015

componenttext: Our next question is from Stephen Grambling from Goldman Sachs.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: I have a few follow-ups to just earlier questions. I guess, first, can you provide any update on the potential credit card sale and remind us on how you're thinking about capital allocation related to those proceeds? And then as an unrelated follow-up, as
componenttext: I have a few follow-ups to just earlier questions. I guess, first, can you provide any update on the potential credit card sale and remind us on how you're thinking about capital allocation related to those proceeds? And then as an unrelated follow-up, as you get to the 300 Rack store target, how are you thinking about the margin for this segment on an absolute basis or even any kind of directional basis you can give relative to the other channels?

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure. Stephen, this is Mike. In terms of the credit card process, as we indicated in our comments, we're very pleased with the progress to date, and we've learned a lot through this process. And actually, it's been more enlightening in terms of how we thi
componenttext: Sure. Stephen, this is Mike. In terms of the credit card process, as we indicated in our comments, we're very pleased with the progress to date, and we've learned a lot through this process. And actually, it's been more enlightening in terms of how we think we can better serve our customers going forward. So we're excited about that. Should we be successful, we would look at the proceeds the same way as the same filters that we've always thought about capital allocation and that is, first and foremost, we always reinvest back in the business. That's where we get the highest returns. And any excess capital that we have, we'll return to shareholders. And we're going to put any proceeds we might get from that through that identical lens. In terms of the Rack, the Rack has and consistently operates with a four-wall operating margin, consistent with the full-line stores. As we go through this accelerated phase, you have a little bit of a uplift because you're recognizing rent on an accelerated basis before the store opens. But as those new stores start to become a smaller piece of the pie, we should see that four-wall contribution start to get back to what is a more normal run rate.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Matt McGinley from Evercore ISI.
componenttext: Our next question is from Matt McGinley from Evercore ISI.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: A lot of moving pieces with Rack in the fourth quarter, so I have kind of a 2-part on Rack. As far as the gross margin, how much of that decline in the gross margin rate was unplanned versus liquidating the inventory position that you'd built in the third
componenttext: A lot of moving pieces with Rack in the fourth quarter, so I have kind of a 2-part on Rack. As far as the gross margin, how much of that decline in the gross margin rate was unplanned versus liquidating the inventory position that you'd built in the third quarter? And then the second part of that, as it played out at the register at Rack, I mean, you had -- you likely had ASP compression, I assume, based on that markdown, but your comp was okay -- was actually better than the third quarter. Did you see a new customer come in? Or did the customer that was coming in the store, otherwise, just had a bigger basket as they saw that price decline?

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: Matt, this is Blake. We talked about in our last call that our inventories were high in the Rack, and so the team worked really hard. And we're pleased that they were able to take that situation and get back in line and be current with our inventory today
componenttext: Matt, this is Blake. We talked about in our last call that our inventories were high in the Rack, and so the team worked really hard. And we're pleased that they were able to take that situation and get back in line and be current with our inventory today in 1 quarter. It did have, as you talked about and mentioned, an impact on the margin. We had to accelerate some markdowns. We didn't see a material change in the average price, nor have we seen any change, let's say, per se with our customer that -- our diverse that shops with us. So the actual execution of the business was fairly consistent. Business did pick up. We don't talk about weather, but when things got a little colder in November, things like outerwear got better and our Rack business got back to a trend that we have seen prior, but the third quarter was a little softer. We think we're in a good position here as we start the New Year both in the Rack and all of our business when it comes to inventory, and so we're really fluid at this point.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon, and thank you for joining us. Today's earnings call will last 45 minutes and will include 30 minutes for your questions. Before we begin, I'd like to mention that our speakers will be referring to slides, which can be viewed by going to
componenttext:
Good afternoon, and thank you for joining us. Today's earnings call will last 45 minutes and will include 30 minutes for your questions. 
Before we begin, I'd like to mention that our speakers will be referring to slides, which can be viewed by going to nordstrom.com in the Investor Relations section. 
Today's discussion may include forward-looking statements, so please refer to the slide showing our safe harbor language. 
Participating in today's call are Blake Nordstrom, President; and Mike Koppel, Chief Financial Officer, who will discuss the company's fourth quarter and 2014 performance, in addition to outlook for fiscal 2015. 
Joining during the Q&A session will be Pete Nordstrom, President of Merchandising; and Erik Nordstrom, President of Direct. 
With that, I'll turn the call over to Blake.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, and good afternoon, everyone. As we reflect on the year, we consider 2014 to be a watershed moment in our company history, with the successful entry into Canada, the expansion of the Rack business through store growth and the launch of Nordstro
componenttext:
Thank you, and good afternoon, everyone. As we reflect on the year, we consider 2014 to be a watershed moment in our company history, with the successful entry into Canada, the expansion of the Rack business through store growth and the launch of NordstromRack.com, the acquisition of the Trunk Club and the decision to explore the potential sale of our credit receivables. These milestones are the outcome of our strategy, which is squarely focused on serving customers on their terms and delivering the Nordstrom experience that they expect from us. 
Several years ago, we began our path to accelerate growth in multiple channels, as we evolve with the changing needs of our customers. In 2014, we delivered tangible results in executing our strategy over the last several years. Today, we made Fortune's list of the World's Most Admired Companies, ranking #14 overall and leading in our category. We continue to see the ongoing evolution of retail with the accelerated growth of e-commerce, the continuing importance of stores and the increasing customer interaction between them. Customers increasingly expect a personalized experience that merges the richness of stores with the convenience of online. We're uniquely positioned to serve customers through our focus on service, product and capabilities. 
We also believe we are competitively advantaged by serving customers better through our multiple touch points in full-price, off-price, stores and online. As a result, we have more customers shopping with us and more customers shopping 2 or more channels. This is meaningful as customers who shop multiple channels spend more and demonstrate greater loyalty. 
In 2014, we reached an important milestone with the Rack representing our biggest source of new customers, attracting nearly 4 million. Additionally, about 1/3 of our Rack customers also shop in our full-line, full-price business. A year ago, we enabled customers to return purchases from HauteLook and NordstromRack.com to any of our Rack stores. This singular capability drove nearly 1 million incremental trips to our Rack stores. 
In 2014, we expanded our capabilities to ensure we're relevant today and in the future. Our first store in Calgary far exceeded our expectations, reflecting a multiyear effort from our team to address the unique challenges of crossing the border.  In the U.S., we increased our presence with 2 full-line stores in Jacksonville, Florida and Houston, Texas. They feature our award-winning design concepts that incorporate flexibility and light.
In the Rack, we reached a record number of 27 store openings, which contributed to Rack's total sales growth of 17%. 
We've expanded our capabilities with the acquisition of HauteLook in 2011, which has grown nearly 150% in 3 years. HauteLook launched NordstromRack.com in the spring, adding to its strong growth trajectory. We more than doubled selections since the launch, which accelerated sales growth for the combined business in the second half of the year. Finally, we strengthened our multichannel capabilities when we acquired Trunk Club, a high-growth business that offers a new approach to personalized service. 
In 2014, we also added capabilities to enhance the customer experience, with an emphasis on convenience. This includes an upgraded point-of-sale system in addition to ongoing enhancements to mobile, the online checkout process and texting tool for our salespeople. We consider our product offering to be a key differentiator in providing customers with the top brands they want. This is enabled through our vendor partnerships, our own product group, where we can provide vendors new channels of distribution that are beneficial for our vendors and the overall customer experience. 
In our full-price business, we've tripled our selection on nordstrom.com since 2011. 
In the Rack, we offer customers great brands at great prices with 48 of the top 50 full-line brands. In addition, when brands participates in dual-flash events on NordstromRack.com and HauteLook, we've seen a lift in brand sales across all 4 channels. 
Most recently, we announced our partnership with Madewell, starting with an offering in 15 stores and online. Similar to our partnerships with Topshop and Charlotte Tilbury, this is another way to enhance our product offering and create excitement for both new and existing customers. 
As we look ahead to 2015, we have a number of growth initiatives planned in support of our efforts to improve the customer experience, including our ongoing expansion in Canada, with a store opening in Ottawa in the spring and Vancouver in the fall. In the U.S., we plan to expand our retail presence with 3 new full-line stores in Puerto Rico, Minneapolis and Milwaukee. We also plan to open 27 Rack stores this year and roughly 25 in 2016. Since we announced our growth plan a couple of years ago, we now see a clear path to reach 300 Rack stores by 2020. 
Our supply chain capabilities are another element in enhancing the customer experience through faster delivery. This fall, we are planning to open a third fulfillment center located in Pennsylvania. Adding fulfillment centers closer to the customer will enable us to offer 2-day shipping for free to more customers. 
We will continue to fuel our fastest-growing businesses through deeper integration of capabilities. Trunk Club doubled its sales in 2014 and is planned to double in sales again this year. From a merchandise perspective, we've enjoyed our partnership with Topshop over the last 2 years, which has attracted new customers to Nordstrom. Based on the great reception we've heard from customers, we expect to expand the offer from roughly 50 to over 80 doors this year. In addition, the new partnership with Madewell is another way for us to provide sought-after brands that appeal to new and existing customers. 
And finally, we view our Nordstrom Rewards loyalty program as an important way for us to deepen our engagement with customers and attract new customers. Rewards members represent 40% of our sales volume. We welcomed over 1 million new members in 2014, a 15% increase from the previous year. We would like to give customers more choices with our loyalty program. Our goal is to provide an integrated, multi-tender program. 
Last year, we piloted an extension of our offering in Texas and in our first store in Canada. Based on the strong customer response, we look forward to rolling out the expanded program to all stores and online in the second half of the year. 
In closing, we are confident in our ability to execute our customer strategy, as we evolve with our customers through our focus on service, product and capabilities. 
With that, I'll turn it over to Mike.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Blake. As we wrap up another year, we are encouraged with the progress we've made in executing our customer strategy. Our efforts to provide best-in-class customer experience are centered on service, product and capabilities. To reinforce Blake'
componenttext:
Thanks, Blake. As we wrap up another year, we are encouraged with the progress we've made in executing our customer strategy. Our efforts to provide best-in-class customer experience are centered on service, product and capabilities. 
To reinforce Blake's comments, our strategy is driven by the changing expectations of our customers. As our business evolves with the customer, the way we create value is evolving, too. 
Over the last several years, we have accelerated our investments to fuel growth across our businesses in full-price, off-price, stores and online. 
About a decade ago, we started on the path of developing our multichannel capabilities by integrating our buying teams and inventory platform. In 2011, we accelerated online growth, starting with enhanced capabilities in e-commerce through the addition of talent, our acquisition of HauteLook and advancements in technology. 
In 2012, we announced our planned investments in new growth opportunities, including our entry into Canada, our Manhattan flagship store and the accelerated expansion of the Rack. Not only do these growth initiatives support our customer strategy, we expect these investments to drive top line growth and deliver returns accretive to our business. Since then, in addition to executing our growth plans, we have increased our focus on our enterprise capabilities to enable a more seamless customer experience. This is reflected in the significant milestones achieved in 2014, including the launch of NordstromRack.com, our successful entry into Canada and the extension of our service approach through the acquisition of Trunk Club. As we look ahead, we plan to further leverage our strategic capabilities through technology, supply chain, merchandising and marketing. 
Now let's turn to our current financial results. We achieved our expectations for 2014, reflecting consistent strength in our sales trends and our investments to fuel growth. We added nearly $1 billion to our top line, with record sales of over $13 billion. Our sales growth of 7.8% and comparable sales increase of 4% were ahead of our expectations. Our ongoing investments contributed to top line growth of roughly 25% from 3 years ago. Not only did our overall business generate growth, we've aggressively invested in Rack stores and e-commerce, which collectively make up over 40% of our sales today, up from 30% 3 years ago. 
Return on invested capital was 12.6%, reflecting a 50-basis-point reduction related to the Trunk Club acquisition and the accelerated pace of capital investments that have roughly doubled since 2011. 
For the sixth consecutive year, we generated operating cash flow in excess of $1 billion. 
Through our balanced capital allocation approach, this past year, we reinvested roughly $750 million back in the business and returned $860 million directly to shareholders through dividends and share repurchases. In addition, we announced last week our quarterly dividend, which increased 12% over last year. 
Earnings per diluted share of $3.72 were consistent with our prior outlook of $3.70 to $3.75. Our results also included a $0.13 reduction from the Trunk Club acquisition, which was incorporated in our prior outlook. 
Now I would like to comment further on our fourth quarter performance. Our earnings per diluted share of $1.32 were a result of continued sales strength and operating execution. We achieved total sales growth of 9% and comparable sales increase of 4.7%, reflecting a strong holiday performance. 
In our full-price business, trends in full-line stores showed sequential improvement over the year, with nordstrom.com demonstrating continued momentum. In our off-price business, the Rack rebounded from the softness experienced late in the third quarter, and our combined channel of NordstromRack.com and HauteLook delivered the highest growth. 
Moving to inventory and gross profit. We corrected our excess inventory at the Rack. We exited the year with inventory aligned to an appropriate level and gross profit performance consistent with our expectations. We are on track to achieve our goals of top-quartile shareholder return, driven by high single-digit sales growth and mid-teens ROIC. We believe this will lead us to be a $20-plus billion business by 2020 while creating significant shareholder value. 
As we shared with you previously, we expect operating margins to reflect the near-term impact of our customer strategy. This includes investments in stores and online growth, the expansion into Canada and foundational capabilities. As a result, we anticipate that these investments will contribute to double-digit increases in depreciation and rent. EBITDAR, which excludes these components, provides an indication of our core operating performance. We continue to focus on profitable growth in our core business, which is reflected by EBITDAR growth in line with sales growth. Additionally, we made meaningful progress in increasing our operating efficiencies, particularly in our full-line business, and continue to evaluate our operating model throughout the company. 
Moving to our capital plan. We expect to invest $4.3 billion or 5% of sales over the next 5 years. Technology is 35% of the plan, reflecting an increased shift towards foundational investments. This includes a merchandising solution that enables our growth and a seamless integration across our multiple channels. It also includes the expansion of our fulfillment network. This not only supports a $2.5 billion online business today that is anticipated to grow by over $1 billion in the next several years, but also enables an integrated customer experience across stores and online. 
New markets, representing Canada and Manhattan, make up 25%, and new stores are 18%. The balance of 22% relates to reinvestment in stores, significantly down from 40% over the last 5 years, into our remodeled prioritization towards high-profile stores and improved efficiencies. 
Now I'd like to provide additional color on our 2015 capital plan of approximately $1.2 billion. Relative to our 5-year capital plan, we expect that this year will represent our peak level of investment at roughly 8% of sales. The step-up in 2015 compared to $750 million in 2014 is primarily driven by new stores, including flagship stores in Vancouver, Toronto and Manhattan. 
In addition, the plan incorporates 3 flagship store remodels in Seattle, Chicago and San Francisco and the new East Coast fulfillment center. As the pace of investment begins to moderate beyond 2015, we expect to see an improvement in earnings growth. 
Finally, I'd like to turn to our 2015 financial outlook. Our plan for earnings per diluted share of $3.65 to $3.80 incorporates total sales growth of 7% to 9%. 
We are planning a comparable store increase of 2% to 4% based on current trends. Our sales outlook assumes in full-price, flat comparable sales at full-line stores and roughly a 20% total sales increase from our online business at nordstrom.com and Trunk Club, with mid-teens growth at nordstrom.com. 
In off-price, Rack total sales growth in the low double digits, with a low single-digit comparable sales increase and roughly a 25% increase from our combined channel of NordstromRack.com and HauteLook. 
Other considerations incorporated in our outlook impacting gross profit and SG&A include the following: the rollout into Canada estimated as an EBIT loss of $60 million compared to $32 million in 2014. This increase includes infrastructure and preopening costs of new stores. As we shared with you previously, we believe this market ultimately represents a $1 billion-plus sales opportunity. We expect this level of loss will begin to decline in 2017 and will become accretive as we reach scale. In addition, we anticipate $30 million in expenses associated with growth enablers, comprised of the additional fulfillment center and our expanded loyalty program planned in the second half of 2015. 
There's also an EBIT loss of roughly $30 million related to Trunk Club compared with a loss of $25 million in 2014. The dilutive impact is expected to moderate in 2016, resulting from increased operating profitability. These growth initiatives contribute to a 20% planned increase in depreciation and rent expense in 2015. 
EBITDAR, when excluding the impact of Canada and Trunk Club, is anticipated to grow roughly with sales. Please also refer to the earnings release for additional assumptions and timing considerations contemplated in our outlook. 
Before we close, we'd like to comment that the process in regards to our potential sale of our credit receivables is expected to ramp up in the first half of 2015. 
We look forward to our opportunities ahead, as we continue on our path to provide a best-in-class customer experience and deliver top-quartile shareholder returns. 
With that, I'll turn the call over to Trina.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: Oliver, this is Blake. I'll take the first part regarding the supply chain. Through the fourth quarter, we had some minor impacts, but we felt it was immaterial. It predominantly, though, can impact flow. And as we have said for some time, our ability to
componenttext: Oliver, this is Blake. I'll take the first part regarding the supply chain. Through the fourth quarter, we had some minor impacts, but we felt it was immaterial. It predominantly, though, can impact flow. And as we have said for some time, our ability to have freshness in flow is important with our customers. So we watch it closely and of late, it's in more of the news. Pete was just in market, and I know a number of the vendors are talking about it. But we have a pretty balanced approach, and we work closely with our vendor partners. And to date, we've been able to manage it fairly well, but our team's watching it closely. I'll turn the gross margin part over to Mike.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. Oliver, this is Mike. Our assumptions in gross margin, what's primarily driving that slight decrease from 2014 is occupancy cost, and it's the occupancy cost related to the continued growth of the Rack as well as the new stores we're opening, particu
componenttext: Yes. Oliver, this is Mike. Our assumptions in gross margin, what's primarily driving that slight decrease from 2014 is occupancy cost, and it's the occupancy cost related to the continued growth of the Rack as well as the new stores we're opening, particularly the new ones in Canada.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Paul Lejuez from Wells Fargo.
componenttext: Our next question is from Paul Lejuez from Wells Fargo.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: Just wondering what you see Trunk Club ultimately growing to on the top line. How do you think about the profitability of that business in a more mature state?
componenttext: Just wondering what you see Trunk Club ultimately growing to on the top line. How do you think about the profitability of that business in a more mature state?

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: Let me take that. This is Erik. As mentioned, Trunk Club had a real high-growth rate, more than doubled last year and on plan to double again this year. We haven't publicly [ph] stated where we think ultimately it can be. But we think it's a big business.
componenttext: Let me take that. This is Erik. As mentioned, Trunk Club had a real high-growth rate, more than doubled last year and on plan to double again this year. We haven't publicly [ph] stated where we think ultimately it can be. But we think it's a big business. I think it is safe to say that. Right now, our focus is mainly around supporting their growth plan. And there's areas like supply chain, alterations, some supply around vendors that we can help them with. We had -- just last week, here in Seattle, their custom business, which, as you may know, they have 3 parts to their business. They have the Trunk business that's basically online, personal styling. They have 5 showrooms, and the third part is their custom business that they take on road before. We actually have that roadshow in our downtown Seattle store last week, and they're just at the very beginning of starting to find some synergies there. So that business, without being specific, I'll say we think it could be very big. The other part is a little less formal and the integration is they can do for our stores. Like that customer experience, we're testing some things there. But we do believe there's a way they can help us. As you know, our personal styling program in our stores is about 1,500 stylists and a very important part of our growth. They do some different things with their styling we think we can learn from them.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: Paul, this is Mike. I would also add, you may recall, when we originally bought the business, we indicated one of the things that we were impressed with was for a startup, how quickly they had moved to breakeven operating profitability. And they -- we're
componenttext: Paul, this is Mike. I would also add, you may recall, when we originally bought the business, we indicated one of the things that we were impressed with was for a startup, how quickly they had moved to breakeven operating profitability. And they -- we're learning a lot in terms of a small business that can scale relatively quickly and that also can apply some of those ways of doing business in a highly personalized way to be very profitable. So we're excited about what we can learn there as well.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Matthew Boss from JPMorgan.
componenttext: Our next question is from Matthew Boss from JPMorgan.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: So on capital priorities, you outlined that this year, the $1.2 billion will be the multiyear peak, and then you talked about an improved earnings growth rate following 2015. Could you just elaborate a little bit on the drivers of that?
componenttext: So on capital priorities, you outlined that this year, the $1.2 billion will be the multiyear peak, and then you talked about an improved earnings growth rate following 2015. Could you just elaborate a little bit on the drivers of that?

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure, Matt. This is Mike. Yes, for 2015, there's a lot going on as we articulated. We've got some significant investments in our store openings in Canada, which include some pretty large stores in Vancouver and Toronto. We have a continued ongoing investm
componenttext: Sure, Matt. This is Mike. Yes, for 2015, there's a lot going on as we articulated. We've got some significant investments in our store openings in Canada, which include some pretty large stores in Vancouver and Toronto. We have a continued ongoing investment in Manhattan, which, right now, is purely a capital investment. But it's a fair amount of capital. And then in addition, we are investing in our infrastructure to support all this growth. This growth is a wonderful thing, but if you don't have the tools and systems to support it, it's not going to work very well. And so what you're seeing here is a kind of a coming together of a lot of activity in this year. Post-2015, as we start to see that -- those capital outlays somewhat moderate and become more consistent, we should see the operating model start to catch up a little bit more to those investments, and we should start to see earnings growth to be a little bit better than it's been the last couple of years.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Dorothy Lakner from Topeka Capital Markets.
componenttext: Our next question is from Dorothy Lakner from Topeka Capital Markets.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: Just wondered if you could provide a little bit more color on what you're seeing in the loyalty business. I mean, clearly, you've continued to see impressive growth there helping to drive sales. And I was just curious, the comment you made about more cust
componenttext: Just wondered if you could provide a little bit more color on what you're seeing in the loyalty business. I mean, clearly, you've continued to see impressive growth there helping to drive sales. And I was just curious, the comment you made about more customers shopping in multiple channels, clearly, that's a great driver, too. So in terms of the number of customers you added, what's the total number of customers you've got in the various loyalty programs at this point? And kind of what percentage of that customer base are actually shopping in multiple channels? And then just a little bit of color on the program that you've -- the expanded program that you piloted, if you could.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure, Dorothy. This is Mike. We've, for the last roughly 5 years, seen some really strong growth in our Nordstrom Rewards program. And that has been driven by a program that has been entirely connected to one of our tenders, whether it's our debit card, w
componenttext: Sure, Dorothy. This is Mike. We've, for the last roughly 5 years, seen some really strong growth in our Nordstrom Rewards program. And that has been driven by a program that has been entirely connected to one of our tenders, whether it's our debit card, whether it's our private-label credit card or a co-branded Visa card. And one of the things that we learned with our pilot this last year is we had a lot of customers out there and a lot of potential future customers that would love to engage with us but don't necessarily want to open up another tender. And so the addition to our overall loyalty offering is going to include a tender-neutral offering, which we're not going to disclose specifics yet, but we will have a way of connecting with those customers other than through a credit card or a debit card. And the tests we have both in Canada and in Texas really have some great results and reinforce to us that this is another way that we can connect and build lifetime loyalty with our customers. Currently, today, we have about 4.3 million active members in the rewards program. Last year, we added about 1 million. Clearly, we add and we attrite as the years go on. So we're constantly looking to engage with new customers.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: And just on the number of those shopping in more -- in one -- more than one channel.
componenttext: And just on the number of those shopping in more -- in one -- more than one channel.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: I don't really have that number with me. But if at some point we have it, we'll certainly share it with you.
componenttext: I don't really have that number with me. But if at some point we have it, we'll certainly share it with you.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Paul Swinand from Morningstar Inc.
componenttext: Our next question is from Paul Swinand from Morningstar Inc.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: A question on -- you're growing the online channel in a number of different ways from the different acquisitions to improve the old acquisitions and, obviously, tie it in your own Rack brand, et cetera. But are you seeing any new or changed productivity i
componenttext: A question on -- you're growing the online channel in a number of different ways from the different acquisitions to improve the old acquisitions and, obviously, tie it in your own Rack brand, et cetera. But are you seeing any new or changed productivity in the way you're acquiring customers or the way you're marketing to customers? In other words, should that get a more efficient marketing productivity over time? Or is it getting harder to acquire customers as the comparison gets tougher?

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: This is Erik. It changes constantly how the different variables, major variables in acquiring customers online. It's going to change year-to-year. They even change month-to-month. So what the mix is, between all those different variables, we're constantly
componenttext: This is Erik. It changes constantly how the different variables, major variables in acquiring customers online. It's going to change year-to-year. They even change month-to-month. So what the mix is, between all those different variables, we're constantly changing the -- it goes a lot to the search engines and market -- search engine optimization that we go through. So I wouldn't say it's necessarily getting harder, but I will say that the mix is constantly changing, and so we have to change accordingly.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: Could you maybe just give us some color on what you're currently seeing for strategies that are working?
componenttext: Could you maybe just give us some color on what you're currently seeing for strategies that are working?

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: No, we really don't get into that.
componenttext: No, we really don't get into that.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Jeff Stein from Northcoast Research.
componenttext: Our next question is from Jeff Stein from Northcoast Research.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: Just want to clarify the profitability outlook for Canada. It sounded to me that 2017 is probably the year when losses are going to start coming down, so I just want to make sure I'm correct in understanding that. It sounds like this will be a year of hig
componenttext: Just want to clarify the profitability outlook for Canada. It sounded to me that 2017 is probably the year when losses are going to start coming down, so I just want to make sure I'm correct in understanding that. It sounds like this will be a year of higher losses and then, again, 2016 will also be a year of even higher. Would that be correct?

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: Jeff, this is Mike. We expect '15 and '16 to be relatively comparable in terms of the losses. And then after we open all the stores and start to get some scale, we'll see that get better in 2017.
componenttext: Jeff, this is Mike. We expect '15 and '16 to be relatively comparable in terms of the losses. And then after we open all the stores and start to get some scale, we'll see that get better in 2017.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. So just from a very high level, in terms of when you start harvesting the benefits of your capital program, it sounds like this is probably going to be kind of the trough year where you see the greatest pressure on earnings. And next year, we'll sti
componenttext: Okay. So just from a very high level, in terms of when you start harvesting the benefits of your capital program, it sounds like this is probably going to be kind of the trough year where you see the greatest pressure on earnings. And next year, we'll still continue to see pressure, but you would see positive earnings growth year-on-year.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: That's currently what we're seeing today.
componenttext: That's currently what we're seeing today.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Barbara Wyckoff from CLSA.
componenttext: Our next question is from Barbara Wyckoff from CLSA.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: Could you talk about the trends in women's sportswear and accessories or the top-performing categories? What's been disappointing? And then if you could comment, please, on your return rates. You're a few years into free shipping and free returns.
componenttext: Could you talk about the trends in women's sportswear and accessories or the top-performing categories? What's been disappointing? And then if you could comment, please, on your return rates. You're a few years into free shipping and free returns.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: This is Pete. In women's sportswear, specifically, where we have had the most success, it's largely kind of around what we would call our young customer segment. And the leading brand and initiative there is the Topshop performance, which has been really
componenttext: This is Pete. In women's sportswear, specifically, where we have had the most success, it's largely kind of around what we would call our young customer segment. And the leading brand and initiative there is the Topshop performance, which has been really very, very good. And I think it was mentioned in the comments, we're expanding from 50 stores to 80 this year, and then the existing stores we're comping really well there. That's been a great catalyst for women's apparel in total. I'd say the other category, women's apparel, [indiscernible] have been pretty good, coats have been pretty good, and dresses have been pretty solid. With accessories, leading the way there has been our handbag business and then our jewelry business. Those have been probably the 2 categories that have been the best performing.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: And returns?
componenttext: And returns?

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: I'll take return rates. This is Erik. We've had free shipping, free returns on nordstrom.com for 3.5 years now and so there really hasn't been any change since then. In off-price, we do charge, I think, for both of those, the important thing for returns,
componenttext: I'll take return rates. This is Erik. We've had free shipping, free returns on nordstrom.com for 3.5 years now and so there really hasn't been any change since then. In off-price, we do charge, I think, for both of those, the important thing for returns, number one, returns is a big strategic subject for us. Being great for customers on returns is something that's long been part of our deal and that certainly includes online. So for us, a big part of the value in our approach to returns is in having returns in the store, so online purchases being able to be returned to our store at -- well over 60% of our nordstrom.com returns end up at our full-line stores. Well over 70% of HauteLook and NordstromRack returns end up at Rack stores. Last year in our Rack stores, that drove, as Blake mentioned an additional million visits to our Rack stores. So there is this absolute synergy. The returns, that's probably the easiest, biggest synergy subject for us to talk about when we talk about the synergies between our stores and online. So it's -- return rates have been pretty stable at nordstrom.com, and what we're seeing more is the benefit of linking to our stores.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Ed Yruma from KeyBanc Capital Markets.
componenttext: Our next question is from Ed Yruma from KeyBanc Capital Markets.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: I guess, first, you guys did a lot to improve pricing transparencies here by kind of doing this, "We will not be undersold." And then also, I guess, by changing the sale pattern that you have. I guess, as you hindsight the year, did you get the kind of gr
componenttext: I guess, first, you guys did a lot to improve pricing transparencies here by kind of doing this, "We will not be undersold." And then also, I guess, by changing the sale pattern that you have. I guess, as you hindsight the year, did you get the kind of gross profit and sales return you would've liked out of those 2 initiatives? And then, I guess, as a follow-up, I think you mentioned that the new DC was to support free 2-day shipping. So I guess, when does that get put into place? And is there any other negative impact to the P&L from that?

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: This is Pete. Well, I think, with regards to the pricing, that was not intended to be a near-term lever to drive results. That's much more of a long-term value proposition with customers based on desire to gain trust and loyalty and confidence over time,
componenttext: This is Pete. Well, I think, with regards to the pricing, that was not intended to be a near-term lever to drive results. That's much more of a long-term value proposition with customers based on desire to gain trust and loyalty and confidence over time, and it's important for us to be transparent on that whole pricing subject. And with the way that online business has done now, the customers are way more enabled, and they've got a lot of information. And we've got to be respectful of that, responsive to it. So that's just driven how we have adjusted some of our pricing philosophies. Most of it is still based in a bit of a reactionary thing. We're trying to run a full-price business here. We have the natural rhythm cycles of markdowns that happen, which gets addressed in our clearance strategy. As you talked about, going from those 2 half yearly's to the 6 clearance events. But the promotional stuff is mostly just a reaction to what happens with some of the competition. That's leveled out a little bit here as the year is going on and where we are now, and that -- things have moderated at least for now. I'm sorry, the second part of the question?

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: I can take that. The new DC opening up. We haven't announced that we're going to free 2-day shipping. The point with us having an additional fulfillment center is it gets closer to a big chunk of customers, or about almost half of our customers are within
componenttext: I can take that. The new DC opening up. We haven't announced that we're going to free 2-day shipping. The point with us having an additional fulfillment center is it gets closer to a big chunk of customers, or about almost half of our customers are within the 2-day ground delivery of that Pennsylvania fulfillment center. And so a bunch of -- a big chunk of our orders for those customers will be 1 to 3 days faster for them than currently is. Now we will still ship some orders from our Cedar Rapids fulfillment center to the northeast. We won't have perfect allocation there. But mainly, we continue to focus on, and the long-term strategy here is to have a fulfillment network that gets practically, at least over 90% of our customers in the United States within a 2-day ground, and this is one step in that direction.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: Ed, the last part of your question -- this is Mike. You asked about the cost of this, and in our comments, we noted that there's an anticipated $30 million increase in expense. We haven't broken out the DC, but that included both the DC and the loyalty pr
componenttext: Ed, the last part of your question -- this is Mike. You asked about the cost of this, and in our comments, we noted that there's an anticipated $30 million increase in expense. We haven't broken out the DC, but that included both the DC and the loyalty program.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Kimberly Greenberger from Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: Our next question is from Kimberly Greenberger from Morgan Stanley.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: Mike, I just wanted to follow up on an earlier comment you made. You mentioned that you expect earnings growth to reaccelerate after the sort of thrust of the investment program. It sounded like that reacceleration would happen around 2017. Is that a corr
componenttext: Mike, I just wanted to follow up on an earlier comment you made. You mentioned that you expect earnings growth to reaccelerate after the sort of thrust of the investment program. It sounded like that reacceleration would happen around 2017. Is that a correct read on it? Or do you think it's more of the 2018 time frame? And then just a clarification on your Trunk Club comments. I think you mentioned that you were all quite impressed with how quickly the Trunk Club business model was able to get to breakeven. I think you mentioned that it delivered a $25 million loss in 2014 for Nordstrom and $30 million in 2015 is expected. Is that differential just a step-up from purchase accounting? Or is there something about acquiring Trunk Club that actually caused them to go from breakeven to a loss situation?

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure. Kimberly, thanks for your questions. On the first one, I think what we were saying is post-2015, we would start to see earnings growth improve. I don't think we used the word accelerate, but we thought it would improve after the peak year 2015 inves
componenttext: Sure. Kimberly, thanks for your questions. On the first one, I think what we were saying is post-2015, we would start to see earnings growth improve. I don't think we used the word accelerate, but we thought it would improve after the peak year 2015 investment. The second part on Trunk Club is we did indicate operating profitability at breakeven. And you're right, the losses are related to the amortization of the purchase accounting, and so that's what contributes to that total $25 million that you mentioned.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Paul Trussell from Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: Our next question is from Paul Trussell from Deutsche Bank.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: $20 billion in sales by 2020 sounds pretty conservative to me. But using your forecast, how should we think about the margin profile of that business? I think you kind of finished this year around 15% EBITDAR, Mike. I mean, how should we think about the n
componenttext: $20 billion in sales by 2020 sounds pretty conservative to me. But using your forecast, how should we think about the margin profile of that business? I think you kind of finished this year around 15% EBITDAR, Mike. I mean, how should we think about the next few years, especially on the SG&A front?

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. Well, Paul, it might sound conservative in the numbers, but it's a heck of a lot of effort to get there. So we think we have a pretty good plan, and $20 billion is a good target for us. But anyway, in terms of how we think about the profitability, I'
componenttext: Yes. Well, Paul, it might sound conservative in the numbers, but it's a heck of a lot of effort to get there. So we think we have a pretty good plan, and $20 billion is a good target for us. But anyway, in terms of how we think about the profitability, I'd go back to what's been our long-standing guidance, and that's been the high single-digit sales growth and mid-teens ROIC. It's very difficult to predict precise margins over short periods of time. But our goal is to achieve -- is to target those 2 numbers and achieving them over that longer period should generate some pretty significant value.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Neely Tamminga from Piper Jaffray.
componenttext: Our next question is from Neely Tamminga from Piper Jaffray.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: Could we dig a little bit more into the Trunk Club innovation timeline? At this point, have you guys flipped the switch, the proverbial switch, whatever that is, with fulfilling Trunk Club orders through Cedar Rapids at this point? Or where are you in tha
componenttext: Could we dig a little bit more into the Trunk Club innovation timeline? At this point, have you guys flipped the switch, the proverbial switch, whatever that is, with fulfilling Trunk Club orders through Cedar Rapids at this point? Or where are you in that progression? And is that contemplated in the 2015 dilutive impact?

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: Neely, it's Erik. No, to answer your question. We are not fulfilling Trunk Club orders out of Cedar Rapids at this point. They have a -- they're doing that out of Chicago. What we're helping them with is -- really, it's part of our supply chain network. W
componenttext: Neely, it's Erik. No, to answer your question. We are not fulfilling Trunk Club orders out of Cedar Rapids at this point. They have a -- they're doing that out of Chicago. What we're helping them with is -- really, it's part of our supply chain network. While it's not in the physical location of Cedar Rapids, our team is supporting that. An easy casual example is we got Trunk Club on our shipping contract with UPS. We've got significant savings with that. And our long-term supply chain strategy is to have everything integrated. It includes our fulfillment centers, our DC, our stores. And long term, we would certainly look for Trunk Club to be part of that. In the short term, they continue to be fulfilled out of Chicago.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Lorraine Hutchinson from Bank of America.
componenttext: Our next question is from Lorraine Hutchinson from Bank of America.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: This is Heather Balsky on for Lorraine. Could you talk a little bit about your inventory plans going forward, especially for the Rack? How are you thinking about pack-and-hold investment? And then also just could you provide some color on how you're getti
componenttext: This is Heather Balsky on for Lorraine. Could you talk a little bit about your inventory plans going forward, especially for the Rack? How are you thinking about pack-and-hold investment? And then also just could you provide some color on how you're getting to the 300 store target for the Rack? What is that based on?

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: Heather, this is Blake. Our pack-and-hold has been fairly consistent now over the last, let's say, 1.5 years or 2 years. It's about 11% of the total company's inventory, and so we continue through the vendor partnerships and relationships to have a terrif
componenttext:
Heather, this is Blake. Our pack-and-hold has been fairly consistent now over the last, let's say, 1.5 years or 2 years. It's about 11% of the total company's inventory, and so we continue through the vendor partnerships and relationships to have a terrific access to product that's closed out in the season that we're able to literally pack and hold in a warehouse and use the following -- 6 months later. It helps us turn the corner in each of the existing stores. It particularly is a key component for the new store growth. We mentioned that we opened 27 stores last year and 27 this year. Pack-and-hold enables us to execute that. So that's an approach with our vendor partnerships and vendor -- or inventory maximization that's -- we're really pleased with them working well. 
In terms of the 300 stores, it's a pretty fluid model opening the Rack's in terms of the lead time, particularly compared to full-line stores. And we're just learning with each one, and we continue to get great reception from the customer. I think it's really reflected in, and we've said this before, in the productivity of the stores. They both maintained and enhanced slightly with the addition of these new stores. So we're encouraged by those opportunities. Sometimes there are some vagaries in the retail or the real estate market year-to-year, but we feel very confident looking ahead between now and 2020, given the criteria we use for new stores, the customer demand, the opportunities that are out there, that we feel very confident to publicly state that we should have 300 stores by 2020.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Stephen Grambling from Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: Our next question is from Stephen Grambling from Goldman Sachs.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: I have a few follow-ups to just earlier questions. I guess, first, can you provide any update on the potential credit card sale and remind us on how you're thinking about capital allocation related to those proceeds? And then as an unrelated follow-up, as
componenttext: I have a few follow-ups to just earlier questions. I guess, first, can you provide any update on the potential credit card sale and remind us on how you're thinking about capital allocation related to those proceeds? And then as an unrelated follow-up, as you get to the 300 Rack store target, how are you thinking about the margin for this segment on an absolute basis or even any kind of directional basis you can give relative to the other channels?

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure. Stephen, this is Mike. In terms of the credit card process, as we indicated in our comments, we're very pleased with the progress to date, and we've learned a lot through this process. And actually, it's been more enlightening in terms of how we thi
componenttext: Sure. Stephen, this is Mike. In terms of the credit card process, as we indicated in our comments, we're very pleased with the progress to date, and we've learned a lot through this process. And actually, it's been more enlightening in terms of how we think we can better serve our customers going forward. So we're excited about that. Should we be successful, we would look at the proceeds the same way, through the same filters that we've always thought about capital allocation and that is, first and foremost, we always reinvest back in the business. That's where we get the highest returns, and any excess capital that we have we'll return to shareholders. And we're going to put any proceeds we might get from that through that identical lens. In terms of the Rack, the Rack has and consistently operates with a 4-wall operating margin, consistent with the full-line stores. As we go through this accelerated phase, you have a little bit of a uplift because you're recognizing rent on an accelerated basis before the store opens. But as those new stores start to become a smaller piece of the pie, we should see that 4-wall contribution start to get back to what is a more normal run rate.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Matt McGinley from Evercore ISI.
componenttext: Our next question is from Matt McGinley from Evercore ISI.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: A lot of moving pieces with Rack in the fourth quarter, so I have kind of a 2-part on Rack. As far as the gross margin, how much of that decline in the gross margin rate was unplanned versus liquidating the inventory position that you'd built in the third
componenttext: A lot of moving pieces with Rack in the fourth quarter, so I have kind of a 2-part on Rack. As far as the gross margin, how much of that decline in the gross margin rate was unplanned versus liquidating the inventory position that you'd built in the third quarter? And then the second part of that, as it played out at the register at Rack, I mean, you had -- you likely had ASP compression, I assume, based on that markdown, but your comp was okay -- was actually better than the third quarter. Did you see a new customer come in? Or did the customer that was coming in the store, otherwise, just had a bigger basket as they saw that price decline?

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2015
componenttextpreview: Matt, this is Blake. We talked about in our last call that our inventories were high in the Rack, and so the team worked really hard. And we're pleased that they were able to take that situation and get back in line and be current with our inventory today
componenttext: Matt, this is Blake. We talked about in our last call that our inventories were high in the Rack, and so the team worked really hard. And we're pleased that they were able to take that situation and get back in line and be current with our inventory today in 1 quarter. It did have, as you talked about and mentioned, an impact on the margin. We had to accelerate some markdowns. We didn't see a material change in the average price, nor have we seen any change, let's say, per se with our customer that -- our diverse customer that shops with us. So the actual execution of the business was fairly consistent. Business did pick up. We don't talk about weather, but when things got a little colder in November, things like outerwear got better and our Rack business got back to a trend that we had been seen prior, but the third quarter was a little softer. We think we're in a good position here as we start the New Year both in the Rack and all of our business when it comes to inventory, and so we're real fluid at this point.
