componenttext: I guess first on the Rack, obviously you commented about the strong performance of new stores. Are you seeing any level from older classes and maybe when you do some of these initial stores, are you seeing any negative impact to performance, one? And then I guess two, we've seen a lot of promotions in the handbag and watch markets, are you seeing any negative impact to those businesses within your store?

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 14, 2015
componenttextpreview: Ed, this is Blake. I will take the Rack part of it. We opened 10 stores in the quarter and then just last week, an 11th [ph] stores. And some of these are in the training area of our existing stores. So we did try to plan appropriate or accordingly to tra
componenttext: Ed, this is Blake. I will take the Rack part of it. We opened 10 stores in the quarter and then just last week, an 11th [ph] stores. And some of these are in the training area of our existing stores. So we did try to plan appropriate or accordingly to transfer sales. We don't see anything unusual there. It did have a very slight impact to the first quarter comp store performance for the Rack, but it's not material enough and we believe to call it out. So there's nothing unusual in transfer sales that.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 14, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, I'll take the price promotion thing with the watches and handbags. I think that's true. I think increased price promotion is not good for the business as far as what Jamie talked about and I would just reiterate the same thing, that the best thing th
componenttext: Yes, I'll take the price promotion thing with the watches and handbags. I think that's true. I think increased price promotion is not good for the business as far as what Jamie talked about and I would just reiterate the same thing, that the best thing that we can have going for us, for a healthy business is newness and not price promotion. So yes, it has to have a bit of a negative impact. But there's always -- there's a lot of hopeful things to be working towards and I think the whole industry is interested in getting back some more regular-priced business. It's been a good counter effect. I think where discussions around newness and the ways that we can evolve this business, so that's compelling to customers to buy new things, and that's happening right now.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 14, 2015

componenttext: Our next question comes from Jeff Stein, North Coast research.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 14, 2015
componenttextpreview: A couple of quick ones, guys. First of all, I'm wondering, do you think there might be some cannibalization in your off-price, online businesses and Nordstrom Rack? Because it looks like you've seen some acceleration on the online segment and at the same
componenttext: A couple of quick ones, guys. First of all, I'm wondering, do you think there might be some cannibalization in your off-price, online businesses and Nordstrom Rack? Because it looks like you've seen some acceleration on the online segment and at the same time, deceleration in the stores. And second question would be the impact of Trunk Club and ongoing entry into Canada, had a $19 million negative effect on Q1. So if you add that back, you're essentially flat and I'm wondering how should we think about that if you back out those kinds of incremental items?

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 14, 2015
componenttextpreview: This is Blake. In regards to HauteLook and NordstromRack.com and its any potential impact to the Rack itself, we've seen a real positive experience in this last year with HauteLook and the Rack. In particular, if we can make it more seamless with the cust
componenttext: This is Blake. In regards to HauteLook and NordstromRack.com and its any potential impact to the Rack itself, we've seen a real positive experience in this last year with HauteLook and the Rack. In particular, if we can make it more seamless with the customer whether its probably while purchase or return, and we think that applies to NordstromRack.com as well. So I understand the question and why you would want to be, pursue that further. Our focus is laying the customers shop, how they want to shop. We look at it totally across-the-board, when we put as an off-price, both online and in the stores, we're really pleased with that gain. Again, we think it was just a very temporary number of issues that contributed to Q1 to being slightly down and what committed to that growing. So I think that question would be more prevalent if you saw in the future that continuing will be to expand above that.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 14, 2015
componenttextpreview: And then the $19 million incremental spend from Trunk Club and Canada, again adding that back, that will only get you the kind of flat EBIT relative to last year?
componenttext: And then the $19 million incremental spend from Trunk Club and Canada, again adding that back, that will only get you the kind of flat EBIT relative to last year?

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 14, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure, Jeff, this is Mike. You're absolutely right about that. There's a number of things going on that are part of our overall strategy. We continue to see an acceleration in the impact of our technology investments. Those are assets that are coming onlin
componenttext: Sure, Jeff, this is Mike. You're absolutely right about that. There's a number of things going on that are part of our overall strategy. We continue to see an acceleration in the impact of our technology investments. Those are assets that are coming online relatively quickly and have a relatively short life, so we continue to see that adding more to the SG&A. We also opened a fair amount of new stores and when you open stores, you have an increase in SG&A where you don't see the commensurate earnings as of yet. So we continue to see some of the pressures of the things that we're doing to grow our business and have the right foundation for the future.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 14, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Neely Tamminga Piper Jaffray.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Neely Tamminga Piper Jaffray.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 14, 2015
componenttextpreview: Just 2 quickies for me. In terms of mobile app for the loyalty program being better integrated for Nordstrom. Are there plans on that to do that also with the Rack HauteLook app, in terms of better utilizing the notes, et cetera and what sort of engagemen
componenttext: Just 2 quickies for me. In terms of mobile app for the loyalty program being better integrated for Nordstrom. Are there plans on that to do that also with the Rack HauteLook app, in terms of better utilizing the notes, et cetera and what sort of engagement are you seeing there? And then real quick on products. Can you talk about NPG for a while? And for what its worth, Nordstrom collection looks amazing right now. And I'm just wondering if the consumers actually demanding more private label from you and that's taking up some of your penetration and the more you guys have been in the past.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 14, 2015
componenttextpreview: Neely, this is Mike. I'll take the first part of the question regarding the mobile app and Trunk Club, and some of our newer businesses. Our plan is to, over time, certainly include those businesses on that program, but we're in the process right now of b
componenttext: Neely, this is Mike. I'll take the first part of the question regarding the mobile app and Trunk Club, and some of our newer businesses. Our plan is to, over time, certainly include those businesses on that program, but we're in the process right now of building out some new foundations for our loyalty program. We're going to introduce a nontender this fall, and I think the important thing is we focus on getting that done first and getting our larger businesses supported by that. And then subsequent to that, we will put the functionality and for some of our regular businesses.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 14, 2015
componenttextpreview: This is Pete, with regards to the NPG question, thanks for noticing. Yes. We've had good NPG business and our sales are growing faster in NPG than it is across our branded business, and it's good. It's been part of our intention and plan and it's been wor
componenttext: This is Pete, with regards to the NPG question, thanks for noticing. Yes. We've had good NPG business and our sales are growing faster in NPG than it is across our branded business, and it's good. It's been part of our intention and plan and it's been working out well. I'd say in particular, some of the strong places where we're performing is we've introduced Rack NPG in a much more purposeful way and that's gone very well. Successful price points, particularly in some of those more trend and young customer departments that we talked about earlier and women's particularly, I think BP and Savvy that's gone extremely well and also in TVD. So across more NPGs performing well, it's an important part of our strategy and we will continue to let it find its level.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 14, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Paul Swinand Morningstar.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Paul Swinand Morningstar.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 14, 2015
componenttextpreview: I just wanted to ask with the Rack online doing so well, but its really a small base. Now that you've got several different online brands, can you give us a little color on what you're finding or learning and the differences are between the brands, and wh
componenttext: I just wanted to ask with the Rack online doing so well, but its really a small base. Now that you've got several different online brands, can you give us a little color on what you're finding or learning and the differences are between the brands, and what's your strategies are from the different brands going forward?

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 14, 2015
componenttextpreview: Paul, this is Erik. I'd say overall, as Blake said earlier, our plan is to provide our customers choices to shop, how they want to shop. One of the interesting things about launching NordstromRack.com is seeing the difference in customers between that bus
componenttext: Paul, this is Erik. I'd say overall, as Blake said earlier, our plan is to provide our customers choices to shop, how they want to shop. One of the interesting things about launching NordstromRack.com is seeing the difference in customers between that business and our HauteLook business. The flash sale business is still a very viable business. The big business is one that we think is really additive to what we do and there is a synergy there, that foundation that HauteLook had was it allowed us to launch Rack.com much sooner than we would have been on our own. We're seeing synergies of those businesses with things like a product, I think our product in NordstromRack.com has improved significantly since launch. There's -- we're continuing to explore some synergies with marketing. But again, there's a point while there are some customers that go back and forth, there's -- there are separate customers. Some customers prefer flash, some categories are stronger than flash and some prefer persistence. So we really like the culmination.

componenttext: A big chunk of your $4.3 billion or CapEx plan for the next 5 years are -- is this year. So should we expect to kind of relatively equal balance over the next 4 years of say $750 million to $800 million or is 2016 perhaps a little bit elevated as well? And also I believe that you mentioned, Mike that these CapEx projects would be funded out of free cash flow. So if you do successfully reach terms on the credit card and it sounds like you're close, what's the priorities with that cash influx? Is buybacks the focus?

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 14, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure, Paul. First, on the CapEx, as we said we expect in the forward years after this year, that the CapEx as a percent of sales will start to -- will be below the average of 5%. Next year, should be measurably lower than it was this year and we should se
componenttext: Sure, Paul. First, on the CapEx, as we said we expect in the forward years after this year, that the CapEx as a percent of sales will start to -- will be below the average of 5%. Next year, should be measurably lower than it was this year and we should see it gradually even off after that. In terms of capital, I would just reiterate at this point in time, we've got a very balanced approach in terms of how we not only invest our capital, but also how we return it to our shareholders. And so should we be successful with the sale of the credit receivables, then we'll apply those lenses and we'll study what the most appropriate way is to deal with that excess capital and we'll certainly let you know of what we decide.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 14, 2015

componenttext: And then I know you don't give very specific quantification or margins per segment, but just given the kind of scale and productivity levels you've reached now with the Rack, can you just kind of remind us or update us on how the margin profile of the Rack business, compares to the other areas particularly the full-line and how we should think about maybe the impact to total EBIT as the Rack becomes a bigger piece of the total?

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 14, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure. The Rack, as we've stated in the past, behaves a little differently than our regular priced business. But when it comes to the contribution, the 4-wall [ph] contribution, it's very similar to the full-line business. So as that business continues to
componenttext: Sure. The Rack, as we've stated in the past, behaves a little differently than our regular priced business. But when it comes to the contribution, the 4-wall [ph] contribution, it's very similar to the full-line business. So as that business continues to grow, its contributing positively to the overall earnings growth of the company. Now that being said, as you go through the investment cycle we're going through right now, it looks a little different. But long-term, that has a great positive contribution. Thank you.

componenttext: Mike, obviously you've got some incremental SG&A expenses flowing through the P&L for the investments that you're making in the business including the expansion that you're engaging in. I'm wondering if you can talk to us about how to think about SG&A dollars going forward and then future years, should we expect any decline in future years, for example, in the actual dollars being spent? Or is it simply a matter of growing the top line over time so that you can leverage the investments that are currently being made?

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 14, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, Kimberly. Well first, with the kind of growth plans we have, its frankly tough to imagine that SG&A would decline. Hopefully, we're in a position that we continue to grow and we're funding that growth. So I don't envision SG&A declining. If you're go
componenttext: Yes, Kimberly. Well first, with the kind of growth plans we have, its frankly tough to imagine that SG&A would decline. Hopefully, we're in a position that we continue to grow and we're funding that growth. So I don't envision SG&A declining. If you're going to get leverage, its going to come from the top line. We continue to look for opportunities. I think you recalibrate elements of our business to make it more efficient as customer preferences are changing and that's helping us. But in terms of AR expectations that SG&A would decline, I wouldn't factor that into your models.

componenttext: My first question is on gross margin. Last year, you had a fairly substantial decline in gross margin as it related to the competitive markdowns you had in Rack and loyalty. And although, there wasn't much movement this quarter, it was up a little bit, I suspect there was some bigger moving process and where it needed, given the volatility you typically have in this line. If you could you give some color on what was the drag or were you better in March  margins or was loyalty more favorable? And Mike, I have a quick follow-up on the share repurchase question. I understand you use a grid, but would you expect to offset the options delusion that your share count will be lower over the course of the year or should we expect this kind of rate that you're at today in terms of share count will be where you are around at the end of the year?

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 14, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure, well, first with the gross margin, there's a few things going on there. I'll tell you from a merchandise margins standpoint, we're relatively even with last year. We had some deleverage and some components of the expense and some leverage in other c
componenttext: Sure, well, first with the gross margin, there's a few things going on there. I'll tell you from a merchandise margins standpoint, we're relatively even with last year. We had some deleverage and some components of the expense and some leverage in other components of the expense that make up that line. The other thing to understand is that the Rack becomes a larger percentage total of the business. Rack has a lower merchandise margin than the rest of the business. And so you're going to have just by the very nature, a mixed impact of that. But our margins overall, we're on plan, so we felt good about performance there. In terms of share repurchase, we, every quarter, we recalibrate our buyback matrix. We still have a substantial amount of authorization left to buy back shares and we're still committed to a balanced approach to reallocating -- to allocating that capital. So I think what you should see in the future would be consistent with what we've done in the past.

componenttext: It has the function of the sell-through within the full-line stores, which Jamie talked about where we always work out to be more efficient. So it's not just a function of store count from full-line to Rack.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 14, 2015

componenttext:
Hello, and welcome to the Nordstrom First Quarter Conference Call. And at the request of Nordstrom, today's conference call is being recorded. [Operator Instructions] 
I will now introduce, Trina Schurman, Director of Investor Relations for Nordstrom. You may begin.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 14, 2015
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon, and thank you for joining us. Today's earnings call will last 45 minutes and will include 30 minutes for your questions.Before we begin, I want to mention that our speakers will be referring to slides, which can be viewed by going to nor
componenttext:
Good afternoon, and thank you for joining us. Today's earnings call will last 45 minutes and will include 30 minutes for your questions.
Before we begin, I want to mention that our speakers will be referring to slides, which can be viewed by going to nordstrom.com in the Investor Relations section.
Today's discussion may include forward-looking statements, so please refer to the slide showing our safe harbor language.
Participating in today's call are Blake Nordstrom, Co-President; and Mike Koppel, Chief Financial Officer, who will discuss the company's first quarter performance in addition to outlook for fiscal year 2015. Joining during the Q&A session will be Co-Presidents Pete and Erik Nordstrom; and Jamie Nordstrom, President of Stores.
I'll now turn the call over to Blake.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 14, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, and good afternoon, everyone. As you know, our customer strategy is squarely focused on serving customers on their terms and delivering the high level of service they expect from us. While we are uniquely positioned to serve customers through m
componenttext:
Thank you, and good afternoon, everyone. As you know, our customer strategy is squarely focused on serving customers on their terms and delivering the high level of service they expect from us. While we are uniquely positioned to serve customers through multiple ways, full-price, off-price, stores and online, we know customers simply view us as Nordstrom.
To support our #1 goal of improving the customer experience, we are focused on a One Nordstrom approach that links our businesses through service, product and capabilities. This is important for our customers and critical in generating long-term profitable growth. 
We've shared our sales ambition of over $20 billion by 2020. To achieve this, increasing customer acquisition and cross-shopping are important outcomes to improve our relevance with both new and existing customers. We've made notable progress over the last year, achieving our strongest gain in new customer growth in recent history. We've also seen increased cross-shopping across our businesses, reflecting our efforts to give customers more choices in how and where they would like to shop.
Turning to our first quarter performance, we're pleased with our results, which were in line with our expectations. Our top line momentum continued with total sales growth of 10% and a comp sales increase of 4.4%. Results reflected disciplined execution and planned growth initiatives. Later, Mike will provide more color on our performance. 
We are encouraged with our ongoing rollout into Canada, which over time, represents $1 billion sales opportunity. In March, we opened our second store in Canada, in Ottawa, Ontario. This fall, we will open our flagship store in Vancouver, which we expect to be one of our largest volume stores. This effort will also strengthen our capabilities leading to our upcoming flagship stores in Toronto and Manhattan. In addition to 6 full-line stores announced in Canada, we also look forward to introducing Nordstrom Rack in the fall of 2017.
In March, we also expanded our full-line presence with our store opening in San Juan, Puerto Rico. In October, we will add to our 116 full-line stores in the U.S. with our second store in Minneapolis and our first in Milwaukee. We are also relocating our South Bay store in Los Angeles to the nearby Del Amo Fashion Center. 
With respect to the Rack, we are on track with our accelerated growth plan, opening 10 stores this quarter. These stores exceeded our expectations and continued to Rack's 12% total sales growth. Just last week, we opened another Rack store in Dublin, California, with 16 more planned this fall. 
A year ago, the HauteLook team launched NordstromRack.com to elevate the Nordstrom experience -- customer experience. The moment continues with our online off-price business, which delivered tremendous sales growth of 50% in the first quarter.
From a merchandise perspective, we're responding to our customers' desire for fresh, relevant brands with the introduction of Charlotte Tilbury, Madewell, Brandy Melville and several others, including those offered in our curated pop-in shops. We're making progress in providing our customers with a shopping experience that is seamless and relevant. For example, we've experienced outsized growth in our BP, Topshop and Savvy departments, particularly where we've created strong adjacencies in our stores. Topshop continues to be a terrific partnership for us, attracting new customers with on-trend fashion at accessible prices. 3 years ago, we started with an offer of 15 doors and online. Based on strong sales performance and customer demand, we plan to expand to roughly 90 doors by the end of the year, from 67 today. 
Our personalization efforts are another way for us to elevate the customer experience. In 2014, we saw tangible results from our mobile enhancements to make shopping easier and more convenient. We've added location-based features that are driving in-store sales and enabling a more seamless experience. More recently, we integrated our rewards program to make it more convenient for customers to receive notifications as well as check and redeem their rewards.
As we looked ahead, in addition to our upcoming store openings, we are on track with our other initiatives to improve the customer experience. This fall, we look forward to providing our customers with faster delivery enabled by our third fulfillment center located in Pennsylvania. Additionally, we will roll out our expanded multi-tender rewards program to all stores and online in the second half of the year.
In closing, our customer strategy is guided by customer expectations around speed, convenience and personalization. We believe we are well positioned to deliver an exemplary experience for our customers, no matter how they choose to shop with us.
With that, I'll turn it over to Mike.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 14, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Blake. Our first quarter performance was on track as we continue to focus on executing our customer strategy. Reinforcing Blake's comments, our #1 goal is to improve the customer experience. Knowing customers increasingly expect both a personalize
componenttext:
Thanks, Blake. Our first quarter performance was on track as we continue to focus on executing our customer strategy. Reinforcing Blake's comments, our #1 goal is to improve the customer experience. Knowing customers increasingly expect both a personalized and convenient experience, we will continue to make investments that enable us to serve customers on their terms.
Our first quarter earnings per diluted share of $0.66 were in line with our expectations. We delivered strong top line results, achieving total sales growth of 10% and a comp increase of 4.4%. Over the past several years, we've been making strategic investments in Canada, Trunk Club and HauteLook. In the first quarter, these businesses added $100 million in sales. As Blake mentioned, our online/off-price business generated an impressive 50% increase, significantly accelerating since the launch of NordstromRack.com, a year ago.
Our full-price business generated a total sales increase of 5%. This included full-line stores' comp increase of 0.5%, reflecting improving trends over the last year. Additionally, Nordstrom.com's momentum continues with a 20% increase. In off-price, the store and online businesses grew 16%. Rack sales were up 12%, reflecting above-plan performance in new stores. Rack had a slight comp decrease of 0.2%. We believe these results are temporary and are maintaining full year expectations of low single digit comp increases at the Rack.
Our EBIT performance in the first quarter reflects planned growth initiatives including Trunk Club and Canada. These initiatives are expected to have a relatively larger dilutive impact in the first half of the year. With our first quarter performance on plan, we are reiterating our full year earnings outlook of $3.65 to $3.80 and sales growth of 7% to 9%. 
Our first quarter performance was consistent with expectations, notably in gross profit, inventory and SG&A. Gross profit increased slightly over the last year by 7 basis points. Our SG&A rate increased roughly 140 basis points over last year, due to our planned investments in Trunk Club, Canada, fulfillment and technology.
Inventory grew 19% over last year compared with sales growth of 10%. We continue to make the necessary inventory investments to fuel our store and online growth. We ended the quarter on plan and current across our businesses. 
Now we'd like to provide additional color on our long-term growth plan. Our strategic investments are a critical driver behind our ambition to deliver a best-in-class customer experience and long-term profitable growth. Over the next 5 years, we plan to invest $4.3 billion in CapEx or roughly 5% of sales, which we plan to fund through our current operations. Approximately $1 billion or 25% is planned for Canada and Manhattan. We view these projects as generational investments to meaningfully elevate our brand and gain market share over the next several decades. We are also investing for growth in existing channels. As our stores represent the core of our brand and the foundation for a multi-channel experience, 40% of our plan will support new store growth and reinvestment. Additionally, technology and fulfillment are key enablers in creating synergies across our business, making up the remainder of the plan at 35%.
We previously shared with you this year's CapEx plan of $1.2 billion or 8% of sales. As we've stated, we expect 2015 to be the peak investment year due to the concurrent timing of multiple growth initiatives. This includes Canada, Manhattan, several flagship remodels and a third fulfillment center. We expect CapEx in subsequent years to normalize below our planned average of 0.5% of sales.
Finally, we'd like to comment on the potential sale of our credit receivables. As a reminder, we started this process a year ago with the goal of maintaining the important relationship we have with our customers while allowing for improvement in our capital efficiency. We are nearing the end of the process and will be in a position to provide an update in the second quarter.
In closing, our focus on serving more customers, while delivering an exemplary experience, is driving both top line sales growth and shareholder returns. We're excited about the momentum in our business and look forward to the opportunities ahead.
With that, I'll turn the call over to Trina.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 14, 2015
componenttextpreview: Oliver, this is Blake. I'll take the Rack part of it. As I mentioned, we're very pleased with the growth and how the new stores are performing. I've commented that we had a very slight decrease in the first quarter on comp store sales basis. Our plan and
componenttext: Oliver, this is Blake. I'll take the Rack part of it. As I mentioned, we're very pleased with the growth and how the new stores are performing. I've commented that we had a very slight decrease in the first quarter on comp store sales basis. Our plan and goals for the year are consistent with our trends previously of low single-digit comp increases. We saw improvement throughout -- towards the end of the quarter there, and we feel really good about our plans and we're committed to that. And so if you ask specifically about what departments are doing better than others? We have a balanced approach in terms of the contribution. And so there's nothing really that I would call out that one area is leading another. We feel good about our Rack business and what the team's doing there.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 14, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. And this is Jamie. I'll take the clearance question. I think we've been talking about the last couple of quarters, we typically given -- or provided 6x inventory turns clear merchandise out, roughly 6 times in a year [indiscernible] department. And w
componenttext: Yes. And this is Jamie. I'll take the clearance question. I think we've been talking about the last couple of quarters, we typically given -- or provided 6x inventory turns clear merchandise out, roughly 6 times in a year [indiscernible] department. And we found that we have opportunities we weren't expecting and how we clear that merchandise out. Clear out the old stuff, make room for the new stuff. Our business is at its best when we have a consistent flow of fresh new goods. So as I think we've been talking about we're trying to make improvements with those clearances to make it more efficient, more compelling for customers and ultimately, we'll have less days of clearance over time. We're on track to do that this year. We are going to be making some changes with what they look like, how they look like online, what we call them, how we communicate with customers. We see some pretty exciting opportunities to make those more effective and that will evolve over the rest of the year.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 14, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Charles Grom, Sterne Agee CRT.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Charles Grom, Sterne Agee CRT.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 14, 2015
componenttextpreview: Just a follow up on Oliver's question. We noticed that you guys look like you're doing a Half-Yearly Sale at the end of May for 10 days across a few categories of business, when we thought I think you guys had abandoned the Half-Yearly Sales. So I was won
componenttext: Just a follow up on Oliver's question. We noticed that you guys look like you're doing a Half-Yearly Sale at the end of May for 10 days across a few categories of business, when we thought I think you guys had abandoned the Half-Yearly Sales. So I was wondering if you could clarify exactly what your promotional strategy is going to be, going forward. Are you going to continue to do that Half Yearlies? Are you going to do the 6 clearance events? Just some clarity on that will be helpful.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 14, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure, Charles. This is Jamie. I'll take that. Just to be clear, we're not a promotional retailer. We're a full-price retailer. We really only have one promotion a year, that's our Anniversary Sale in July. The Half-Yearly clearance events -- ours is that
componenttext: Sure, Charles. This is Jamie. I'll take that. Just to be clear, we're not a promotional retailer. We're a full-price retailer. We really only have one promotion a year, that's our Anniversary Sale in July. The Half-Yearly clearance events -- ours is that it's a clearance event and we've experimented a little bit with communicating those clearance events using different titles, different marketing techniques. A Half Yearly is a brand that we've used over the years to communicate what that event is all about. But we typically use that last weekend, Memorial Day weekend, in May to clear out a big chunk of our early spring assortment and make room for -- more room for the anniversary goods that are coming in. So really nothing has changed about that. We are going from having that late May event from just women's and kids' to include men's as well. So it's all stores, they're all store event. And again now, it continues to evolve. And we think that over time, it's really by the end of this year, we'll be able to be more effective with how we can clear that merchandise out and ultimately have less days of clearance in our stores throughout the year.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 14, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question here comes from Lorraine Hutchinson, Bank of America.
componenttext: Our next question here comes from Lorraine Hutchinson, Bank of America.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 14, 2015
componenttextpreview: With the understanding that some of the specific investments related to fulfillment and others are front-end loaded, are there any other factors that we should consider in forecasting a nice acceleration in earnings growth in the back half?
componenttext: With the understanding that some of the specific investments related to fulfillment and others are front-end loaded, are there any other factors that we should consider in forecasting a nice acceleration in earnings growth in the back half?

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 14, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. Lorraine, this is Mike. A nice acceleration, I don't know if I change it into nice acceleration. Clearly, for this year, we've been pretty clear as to what the expectations are for the year. We do believe that by the fourth quarter, a couple of the i
componenttext: Yes. Lorraine, this is Mike. A nice acceleration, I don't know if I change it into nice acceleration. Clearly, for this year, we've been pretty clear as to what the expectations are for the year. We do believe that by the fourth quarter, a couple of the items, particularly Canada and Trunk Club will start to moderate in terms of the impact and year-over-year earnings. So we should see some improvement there. But we continue to see our core business operating very well and delivering very strong returns. And these investments we're making for the long-term are putting a little short-term drag on those results. But clearly, they're starting to accrue to the top line, and so we believe over time, we're going to get to the bottom line.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 14, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Matthew Boss, JPMorgan.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Matthew Boss, JPMorgan.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 14, 2015
componenttextpreview: This is actually [indiscernible] for Matt. New store productivity was strong in the quarter. How indicative of this is -- how indicative is this of your initial performance in Canada? And then anything new on learnings from your initial store rollout in t
componenttext: This is actually [indiscernible] for Matt. New store productivity was strong in the quarter. How indicative of this is -- how indicative is this of your initial performance in Canada? And then anything new on learnings from your initial store rollout in the region?

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 14, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. So I'll talk about Canada. This is Jamie. I've been told I needed to speak up, so we're sorry if it's a little quiet. As we talked about with Calgary, we had a great start there and that continued. A little softer start in Ottawa. We opened that stor
componenttext: Yes. So I'll talk about Canada. This is Jamie. I've been told I needed to speak up, so we're sorry if it's a little quiet. As we talked about with Calgary, we had a great start there and that continued. A little softer start in Ottawa. We opened that store in middle March, early March. It's really cold up there and we opened with our spring assortment. I will tell you that as it warmed up over the last month, our business has improved. We're very, very encouraged to this date about our performance there, both in Calgary and Ottawa, year-to-date. We're very excited about Vancouver, opening September 19 -- 18, sorry. September 18. As Blake mentioned, we think that has the opportunity -- one of our very best stores in our company and we've got a lot of work going on there. So we continue to be very encouraged about Canada and very bullish on our future there.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 14, 2015
componenttextpreview: And then I was going to ask a question on buyback, but go ahead.
componenttext: And then I was going to ask a question on buyback, but go ahead.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 14, 2015
componenttextpreview: So I was just going to say on store productivity, I thought you were also [indiscernible] be inclusive of the Rack. And as I mentioned, these new stores are outperforming and we've included the Rack as we accelerated the growth that the productivity of th
componenttext: So I was just going to say on store productivity, I thought you were also [indiscernible] be inclusive of the Rack. And as I mentioned, these new stores are outperforming and we've included the Rack as we accelerated the growth that the productivity of these stores are staying consistent. We haven't seen any decline with the addition of these stores. So overall, we're very encouraged.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 14, 2015
componenttextpreview: Got it. And then buyback was a little lower in the quarter. Is there any reason for this? Or any change in how you're thinking about capital allocation going forward?
componenttext: Got it. And then buyback was a little lower in the quarter. Is there any reason for this? Or any change in how you're thinking about capital allocation going forward?

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 14, 2015
componenttextpreview: Matt, this is Mike. No, there's no change in our approach. I mean we set up a buyback plan matrix ahead of time. Its governed through a 10b5-1 plan. It was purely a function of the repurchase amounts that we set based on share price. So no, there's no cha
componenttext: Matt, this is Mike. No, there's no change in our approach. I mean we set up a buyback plan matrix ahead of time. Its governed through a 10b5-1 plan. It was purely a function of the repurchase amounts that we set based on share price. So no, there's no change in our long-term view on share buybacks.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 14, 2015
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Dorothy Lakner, Topeka Capital Markets.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Dorothy Lakner, Topeka Capital Markets.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 14, 2015
componenttextpreview: Just wondered, you've seen a real comeback in the BP business and certainly, it sounds like Topshop and Savvy, I mean those 3 together really created some momentum for you. So I just wondered if you could speak a bit to that. And then just, you also spoke
componenttext: Just wondered, you've seen a real comeback in the BP business and certainly, it sounds like Topshop and Savvy, I mean those 3 together really created some momentum for you. So I just wondered if you could speak a bit to that. And then just, you also spoken about acceleration in cross-shopping, so I wondered if you could put a little color around that as well?

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 14, 2015
componenttextpreview: This is Pete. With regards to the improvement that we've had in Women's Apparel, most specifically around, I guess, what we would call our young customers zone, that's inclusive of Topshop and BP and Savvy. I think the major catalysts there has been Topsh
componenttext: This is Pete. With regards to the improvement that we've had in Women's Apparel, most specifically around, I guess, what we would call our young customers zone, that's inclusive of Topshop and BP and Savvy. I think the major catalysts there has been Topshop where we've had that and been able to integrate it and create adjacencies related to BP and Savvy, it's worked extremely well. And when you combine all those areas together, I think it makes a pretty powerful statement for that -- for that trend customer and that's worked well. So I think the adjustments that have been made is our ability to be able to bring those departments next to each other. All of our stores are a little bit different in terms of how they're laid out, so it's taken some time to kind of create the synergy and adjacencies that we need to. And now that we mostly have that accomplished, it seemed to benefit that and the business is very strong. And sorry -- and the other question was about?

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 14, 2015
componenttextpreview: On cross-shopping.
componenttext: On cross-shopping.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 14, 2015
componenttextpreview: Cross-shopping between what?
componenttext: Cross-shopping between what?

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 14, 2015
componenttextpreview: Between the channels.
componenttext: Between the channels.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 14, 2015
componenttextpreview: The channels.
componenttext: The channels.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 14, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, Dorothy, I think in terms of the cross-shopping, a couple of things that I'll note there, as we called out last fall when we launched NordstromRack.com and HauteLook, the large amount of activity that we were driving back into the Rack stores drew 2
componenttext: Yes, Dorothy, I think in terms of the cross-shopping, a couple of things that I'll note there, as we called out last fall when we launched NordstromRack.com and HauteLook, the large amount of activity that we were driving back into the Rack stores drew 2 returns. That was a very good example of driving customers across channels. We've also seen Rack acquire a substantial amount of new customers that ultimately migrate to our regular price business. And of course over time, we've seen a lot of shopping across between full-line stores and Nordstrom.com. So I think all the initiatives and the various strategies we've put in place continue to bring those barriers down and make it easy for customers to shop.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 14, 2015
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Ed Yruma, KeyBanc Capital Markets.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Ed Yruma, KeyBanc Capital Markets.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 14, 2015
componenttextpreview: I guess first on the Rack, obviously you commented about the strong performance of new stores. Are you seeing any levels of relative maturation amongst some of your older classes and maybe when you do some of these infill stores, are you seeing an negativ
componenttext: I guess first on the Rack, obviously you commented about the strong performance of new stores. Are you seeing any levels of relative maturation amongst some of your older classes and maybe when you do some of these infill stores, are you seeing an negative impact to performance? One, and then, I guess, two, we've seen a lot of promotions in the handbag and watch markets, are you seeing any negative impact to those businesses within your store?

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 14, 2015
componenttextpreview: Ed, this is Blake. I will take the Rack part of it. We opened 10 stores in the quarter and then just last week, an 11th store. And some of these stores are in the training area of our existing stores. And so we do try to plan appropriate or accordingly to
componenttext: Ed, this is Blake. I will take the Rack part of it. We opened 10 stores in the quarter and then just last week, an 11th store. And some of these stores are in the training area of our existing stores. And so we do try to plan appropriate or accordingly to transfer sales. We don't see anything unusual there. It did have a very slight impact to the first quarter comp store performance for the Rack's, but it's not material enough and we believe to call it out. So there's nothing unusual that transfer sales that I think will speak to...

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 14, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, I'll take the price promotion thing with the watches and handbags. I think that's true. An increased price promotion is not good for the business as far as what Jamie talked about and I would just reiterate the same thing, that the best thing that we
componenttext: Yes, I'll take the price promotion thing with the watches and handbags. I think that's true. An increased price promotion is not good for the business as far as what Jamie talked about and I would just reiterate the same thing, that the best thing that we can have going for us, for a healthy business, is newness and not price promotion. So yes, it has to have a bit of a negative impact. But there's always -- there's a lot of hopeful things to be working towards and I think the whole industry is interested in getting back some more regular-price business. So it's been a good counter-effect thing for discussions around newness and the ways that we can evolve this business, so that's compelling to customers to buy new things, and that's happening right now.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 14, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Jeff Stein, North Coast Research.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Jeff Stein, North Coast Research.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 14, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, a couple of quick ones, guys. First of all, I'm wondering, is -- are you -- do you think there might be some cannibalization in your off-price/online businesses and Nordstrom Rack? Because it looks like you've seen some acceleration in the online seg
componenttext: Yes, a couple of quick ones, guys. First of all, I'm wondering, is -- are you -- do you think there might be some cannibalization in your off-price/online businesses and Nordstrom Rack? Because it looks like you've seen some acceleration in the online segment and at the same time, deceleration in the stores. And second question would be the impact of Trunk Club and ongoing entry into Canada, had a $19 million negative effect on Q1. So if you add that back, you're essentially flat and I'm wondering how should we think about that if you'd back out those kinds of incremental items.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 14, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, this is Blake. In regards to HauteLook and NordstromRack.com and its any potential impact to the Rack itself, we've seen a real positive experience in this last year with HauteLook and the Rack. In particular, if we can make it more seamless for the
componenttext: Well, this is Blake. In regards to HauteLook and NordstromRack.com and its any potential impact to the Rack itself, we've seen a real positive experience in this last year with HauteLook and the Rack. In particular, if we can make it more seamless for the customer whether its probably who want to purchase or return, and we think that applies to NordstromRack.com as well. So I understand the question and why you would want to be -- pursue that further. But our focus is laying the customer shop -- how they want to shop. We look at it totally across the board, when we put as an off-price, both online and in the stores, we're really pleased with that gain. And again, we think it was just a very temporary number of issues that contributed to Q1 to being slightly down and we're committed to that growing. So I think that question would be more prevalent if you saw in the future that continuing, we would be to expand upon that.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 14, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then the $19 million incremental spend from Trunk Club and Canada, again adding that back, that will only get you the kind of flat EBIT relative to last year?
componenttext: Okay. And then the $19 million incremental spend from Trunk Club and Canada, again adding that back, that will only get you the kind of flat EBIT relative to last year?

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 14, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure, Jeff, this is Mike. You're absolutely right about that. There's a number of things going on that are part of our overall strategy. We continue to see an acceleration in the impact of our technology investments. Those are assets that are coming onlin
componenttext: Sure, Jeff, this is Mike. You're absolutely right about that. There's a number of things going on that are part of our overall strategy. We continue to see an acceleration in the impact of our technology investments. Those are assets that are coming online relatively quickly and have a relatively short life, so we continue to see that adding more to the SG&A. We also opened a fair amount of new stores and when you open stores, you have an increase in SG&A where you don't see the commensurate earnings as of yet. So we continue to see some of the pressures of the things we're doing to grow our business and have the right foundation for the future.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 14, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Neely Tamminga, Piper Jaffray.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Neely Tamminga, Piper Jaffray.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 14, 2015
componenttextpreview: Just 2 quickies for me. In terms of mobile app for the loyalty program being better integrated for Nordstrom, are there plans on that to do that also with the Rack/HauteLook app, in terms of better utilizing the notes, et cetera, and what sort of engageme
componenttext: Just 2 quickies for me. In terms of mobile app for the loyalty program being better integrated for Nordstrom, are there plans on that to do that also with the Rack/HauteLook app, in terms of better utilizing the notes, et cetera, and what sort of engagement are you seeing there? And then real quick on products, if you can talk about NPG for a while? And for what its worth, Nordstrom collection looks amazing right now. And I'm just wondering if the consumers actually demanding more private label from you and that's taking up some of your penetration and the more you guys have been in the past.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 14, 2015
componenttextpreview: Neely, this is Mike. I'll take the first part of the question regarding the mobile app and Trunk Club, and some of our newer businesses. Our plan is to, over time, certainly include those businesses on that program, but we're in the process right now of b
componenttext: Neely, this is Mike. I'll take the first part of the question regarding the mobile app and Trunk Club, and some of our newer businesses. Our plan is to, over time, certainly include those businesses on that program, but we're in the process right now of building out some new foundations for our loyalty program. We're going to introduce a nontender this fall, and I think the important thing is we focus on getting that done first and getting our larger businesses supported by that. And then subsequent to that, we will put the functionality in for some of our regular businesses.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 14, 2015
componenttextpreview: This is Pete. With regards to the NPG question, thanks for noticing. Yes, we've had good NPG business and our sales are growing faster in NPG than it is across our branded business, and it's good. It's been part of our intention and plans and it's been wo
componenttext: This is Pete. With regards to the NPG question, thanks for noticing. Yes, we've had good NPG business and our sales are growing faster in NPG than it is across our branded business, and it's good. It's been part of our intention and plans and it's been working out well. I'd say in particular, some of the strong places where we're performing is we've introduced Rack NPG in a much more purposeful way and that's gone very well. Successful price points, particularly in some of those more trend and young customer departments that we talked about earlier and women's particularly, I think BP and Savvy that's gone extremely well and also in TBD. So across more NPGs performing well, it's an important part of our strategy, and we will continue to let it find its level.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 14, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Paul Swinand, Morningstar.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Paul Swinand, Morningstar.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 14, 2015
componenttextpreview: I just wanted to ask with the Rack online doing so well on its -- but its really a small base. Now that you've got several different online brands, can you give us a little color on what you're finding or learning and the differences are between the brand
componenttext: I just wanted to ask with the Rack online doing so well on its -- but its really a small base. Now that you've got several different online brands, can you give us a little color on what you're finding or learning and the differences are between the brands, and what's your strategies are from the different brands going forward?

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 14, 2015
componenttextpreview: Paul, this is Erik. I'd say overall, as Blake said earlier, that our plan is to provide our customers choices to shop, how they want to shop. One of the interesting things about launching NordstromRack.com is seeing the difference in customers between tha
componenttext: Paul, this is Erik. I'd say overall, as Blake said earlier, that our plan is to provide our customers choices to shop, how they want to shop. One of the interesting things about launching NordstromRack.com is seeing the difference in customers between that business and our HauteLook business. The flash sale business is still a very viable business. The big business is one that we think is really additive to what we do and there is a synergy there, that's foundation that HauteLook had was it allowed us to launch Rack.com much sooner than we would have been on our own. So we're seeing synergies of those businesses and things like a product, I think our product in NordstromRack.com has improved significantly since launch. There's -- we're continuing to explore some synergies with marketing. But again, there's a point while there are some customers that go back and forth, there's -- there are separate customers. Customers -- some customers prefer flash, some categories are stronger than flash and some prefer persistence. So we really like the combination.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 14, 2015
componenttextpreview: Interesting. And do you think they'll all -- do they add to your inventory turn? Do you think your inventory turn can still continue to improve?
componenttext: Interesting. And do you think they'll all -- do they add to your inventory turn? Do you think your inventory turn can still continue to improve?

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 14, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes.
componenttext: Yes.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 14, 2015
componenttextpreview: And the next question comes from Paul Trussell, Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: And the next question comes from Paul Trussell, Deutsche Bank.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 14, 2015
componenttextpreview: A big chunk of your $4.3 billion CapEx plan for the next 5 years are is this year, so should we expect to kind of relatively equal balance over the next 4 years of say $750 million to $800 million? Or is 2016 perhaps a little bit elevated as well? And als
componenttext: A big chunk of your $4.3 billion CapEx plan for the next 5 years are is this year, so should we expect to kind of relatively equal balance over the next 4 years of say $750 million to $800 million? Or is 2016 perhaps a little bit elevated as well? And also I believe that you mentioned, Mike, that these CapEx projects would be funded out of free cash flow. So if you do successfully reach terms on the credit card and it sounds like you're close, what's the priorities with that cash influx? Is buybacks the focus?

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 14, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure, Paul. First, on the CapEx, as we said we expect in the forward years after this year, that the CapEx as a percent of sales will start to -- will be below the average of 5%. Next year, should be measurably lower than it was this year and we should se
componenttext: Sure, Paul. First, on the CapEx, as we said we expect in the forward years after this year, that the CapEx as a percent of sales will start to -- will be below the average of 5%. Next year, should be measurably lower than it was this year and we should see it gradually even off after that. In terms of capital, I would just reiterate at this point in time, we've got a very balanced approach in terms of how we not only invest our capital, but also how we return it to our shareholders. And so should we be successful with the sale of the credit receivables, then we'll apply those lenses and we'll study what the most appropriate way is to deal with that excess capital and we'll certainly let you know of what we decide.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 14, 2015
componenttextpreview: I appreciate that. And then I know you don't give very specific quantification or margins per segment, but just given the kind of scale and productivity levels you've reached now with the Rack, can you just kind of remind us or update us on how the margin
componenttext: I appreciate that. And then I know you don't give very specific quantification or margins per segment, but just given the kind of scale and productivity levels you've reached now with the Rack, can you just kind of remind us or update us on how the margin profile of the Rack business compares to the other areas particularly the full-line? And how we should think about maybe the impact to total EBIT as the Rack becomes a bigger piece of the total?

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 14, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure. Well, the Rack, as we've stated in the past, behaves a little differently than our regular-price business. But when it comes to the contribution, the four-wall contribution, it's very similar to the full-line business. So as that business continues
componenttext: Sure. Well, the Rack, as we've stated in the past, behaves a little differently than our regular-price business. But when it comes to the contribution, the four-wall contribution, it's very similar to the full-line business. So as that business continues to grow, it's contributing positively to the overall earnings growth of the company. Now that being said, as you go through the investment cycle we're going through right now, it looks a little different. But long term, that has a very positive contribution. Thank you.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 14, 2015
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Michael Binetti, UBS.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Michael Binetti, UBS.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 14, 2015
componenttextpreview: If -- interestingly, if the -- you talked about your confidence in the Rack business accelerating. Maybe just a little bit more on some of the components of what you saw in the quarter relative to that slowing down. I don't even know if anybody has asked
componenttext: If -- interestingly, if the -- you talked about your confidence in the Rack business accelerating. Maybe just a little bit more on some of the components of what you saw in the quarter relative to that slowing down. I don't even know if anybody has asked this, the West Coast port issues had any impact on you there. Then also, you articulated some confidence in that reaccelerating through the year, maybe if you could talk about what gives you confidence there or any of the details behind that?

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 14, 2015
componenttextpreview: Mike, this is Blake. Regarding the port, we're no different than the other business that had some minor impacts to them, but we just didn't think it was material [indiscernible] later date to call out. So for us, it didn't have an impact on the figures th
componenttext: Mike, this is Blake. Regarding the port, we're no different than the other business that had some minor impacts to them, but we just didn't think it was material [indiscernible] later date to call out. So for us, it didn't have an impact on the figures that warranted further explanation. In terms of the business, we talked about it a little bit. We debated a little bit prior to the call, should we go through some of the very minor nuances that maybe could have contributed to the Rack having a slight decrease? Again, we've just seen some improvement there. We're going against for last year, the best performance we had in a 2-year time period in terms of the Q1. But there were a number of little contributions that created that decrease, but we're very confident about our plans for the year and our ability to continue with the trends we've had in the past, and the budget we had of low single digit. And again, we think the results of late are demonstrating that. And so we put [indiscernible]

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 14, 2015
componenttextpreview: And then if I could just follow that for a second, it's -- I would say you're one of the few soft-line companies I've seen who's sales in the first quarter came in above the plan for the year. Maybe taken a little bit of pressure off the rest of the year
componenttext: And then if I could just follow that for a second, it's -- I would say you're one of the few soft-line companies I've seen who's sales in the first quarter came in above the plan for the year. Maybe taken a little bit of pressure off the rest of the year in hitting your targets. If you are able to accelerate the Rack, and I don't know that you're going to tell me that you expect one of the other banners to slowdown, Mike, would you're -- given that you've already articulated your multi-year investment plan to us, would your preference be to let some of the EPS flow through the rest of the year? Or are there a few investments that you look at and you say, we you could speed those up if things came in better than we thought?

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 14, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, Michael, I don't think any change in the sales pattern, particularly on the upside, is going to change our current game plan for the year. We've got a lot on our plate. We're running real hard to get everything done. So if we're able to generate some
componenttext: Yes, Michael, I don't think any change in the sales pattern, particularly on the upside, is going to change our current game plan for the year. We've got a lot on our plate. We're running real hard to get everything done. So if we're able to generate some incremental flow-through, that likely will be the case.

componenttext: Okay, so I guess I'll answer the second part of that. This is Mike. Well, this year, in terms of free cash flow, I think we've said that this was going to be a year where we're not going to generate excess free cash flow, mostly because of our CapEx plan. By the end of the year, cash levels will be approximately where they are now. I think they're roughly by $800 million right now. They're probably between $600 million to $800 million depending how the business performs.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 14, 2015
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Kimberly Greenberger, Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Kimberly Greenberger, Morgan Stanley.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 14, 2015
componenttextpreview: Mike, obviously you've got some incremental SG&A expenses flowing through the P&L for the investments that you're making in the business including the expansion that you're engaging in. I'm wondering if you can talk to us about how to think about SG&A dol
componenttext: Mike, obviously you've got some incremental SG&A expenses flowing through the P&L for the investments that you're making in the business including the expansion that you're engaging in. I'm wondering if you can talk to us about how to think about SG&A dollars going forward and then future years, should we expect any decline in future years, for example, in the actual dollars being spent? Or is it simply a matter of growing the top line over time so that you can leverage the investments that are currently being made?

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 14, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, Kimberly, well, first, with the kind of growth plans we have, it's frankly tough to imagine that SG&A will decline. Hopefully, we're in a position that we continue to grow and we're funding that growth. So I don't envision SG&A declining. If you're g
componenttext: Yes, Kimberly, well, first, with the kind of growth plans we have, it's frankly tough to imagine that SG&A will decline. Hopefully, we're in a position that we continue to grow and we're funding that growth. So I don't envision SG&A declining. If you're going to get leverage, it's going to come from the top line. We continue to look for opportunities. I think to recalibrate elements of our business, to make it more efficient as customer preferences are changing and that's helping us. But in terms of your expectations that SG&A would decline, I wouldn't factor that into your models.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 14, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Matt McGinley, Evercore ISI.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Matt McGinley, Evercore ISI.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 14, 2015
componenttextpreview: My question -- my first question is on gross margin. Last year, you had a fairly substantial decline in gross margin as it related to the competitive markdowns you had in Rack and loyalty. And although, there wasn't much movement this quarter, it was up a
componenttext: My question -- my first question is on gross margin. Last year, you had a fairly substantial decline in gross margin as it related to the competitive markdowns you had in Rack and loyalty. And although, there wasn't much movement this quarter, it was up a little bit, I suspect there was some bigger moving pieces, that were underneath, that given the volatility you've typically have in this line. And if you could you give some color on what was the drag or were you better in March margins or was loyalty more favorable? And Mike, I have a quick follow-up on the share repurchase question. I understand you use a grid, but would you expect to offset the options dilution that your share count would be lower over the course of the year? Or should we expect this kind of rate that you're at today in terms of share count would be -- where you'd be at around at the end of the year?

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 14, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure. Well, first with the gross margin, there's a few things going on there. I'll tell you from a merchandise margin standpoint, we're relatively even with last year. We had some deleverage and some components of the expense and some leverage in other co
componenttext: Sure. Well, first with the gross margin, there's a few things going on there. I'll tell you from a merchandise margin standpoint, we're relatively even with last year. We had some deleverage and some components of the expense and some leverage in other components of the expense that make up that line. The other thing to understand is that the Rack becomes a larger percentage total of the business. Rack has a lower merchandise margin than the rest of the business. And so you're going to have just, by the very nature, a mixed impact of that. But our margins, overall, we're on plan, so we felt good about the performance there. In terms of share repurchase, we, every quarter, we recalibrate our buyback matrix. We still have a substantial amount of authorization left to buy back shares and we're still committed to a balanced approach to reallocating -- to allocating that capital. So I think what you should see in the future would be consistent with what we've done in the past.

headline: Nordstrom Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 14, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. So it has the function of the sell-through is within the full-line stores, which Jamie talked about, where we always work out to be more efficient. But as we add more stores percentagewise, it comes down a little bit. I do think it's important to not
componenttext: Yes. So it has the function of the sell-through is within the full-line stores, which Jamie talked about, where we always work out to be more efficient. But as we add more stores percentagewise, it comes down a little bit. I do think it's important to note that you should look at it as well as a full-price business and off-price business. So as we have a more robust e-commerce business in full-price, there's a portion of goods there too that we cleared to the Rack. So it's not just a function of store count from full-line to Rack.
